reviewText:
First things first... The graphics are amazing. For me, it's the first time that I played where you are in the tropics and can swim in the waters. Each level as you progress shows off a different part of the day. Morning, mid day, evening and night. The game play is straight forward, you also have an open range to wander but, it gets redundant at one point. Best to stay on track and enjoy the scenery either by running, driving, motorboating, and even by hang glider.

Kill the bad guys, kill the monsters too, they can be scary at times, some of them move fast. You can use machine guns, sniper rifes, pistols and even throw rocks to create distractions. Typical FPS game and well what's differnt too is that your game difficulty depends on how you deal with the bad guys. Sometimes you have to use stealth to get by or face a barage of angry mercs.

The game is worth playing. Check out any youtube videos on it. I have played this quite a few times already before it was on steam.

reviewText:
Fun game!

Far Cry is really inventive and seems ahead of its time in many respects. Once you get over the slightly dated graphics, you'll notice all the enjoyable things that make the hours fly by.
The gameplay is excellent, and the level design is very good. Each time I felt the game might begin to feel repetitive, some new elements were introduced, and had me hooked right back in. There are cars, boats, choppers, turrets, tunnels, ruins, fortresses, mercenaries, monsters... Lots of things to get excited about, lots of variation.

I'm a pretty decent FPS guy, and I always go for the normal" setting

reviewText: Replayed this game. I'll start off again with the great stunning visuals within this game (of it's time.) Best part of all, you don't need anything too high-end to play this title. The story is rather short and but clear enough to understand the premis of the game. Cutscenes happen almost instantly and you resume playing in an instant as well. Almost makes you wonder what had just happend after the short duration. Gameplay is rather repetitive. You kill, and kill some more. Unlike the other Far Cry games in the franchise, you can't really attempt stealth in this game. Enemies will spot you from afar. Leaving you in a gunfight against a great number of enemies. The game is also rather hard. Mainly because shooting one enemy will alert the rest. Again, no stealth feature was implemented. Despite all the setbacks, it is still a good game back in it's day (still is.) If you're a fan of games that consists of guns blazing. This would be a game to add to your library. I recommend!

reviewText: I never payed attention to this game when it first came out, I wasn't and am still not the biggest fan of first person shooters.  On a revisit though, this game isn't half bad.  You have to be exceptionally stealthy and tactics matter.  Go in guns blazing guaratees your death.  Even at ten years old the AI of the enemy is good enough to really hurt your ability to advance.  The setting is even interesting from a historical stanpoint.  The game is very long with some interesting level design for most of the game, and to give it some more legs you are given a serviceable story with incredibly bad acting, think 80s action movies.  With that they introduce some scifi elements that really detract from the good enemy AI, think mutants, but it didn't stop me from playing to the end.\n\nI recommend it on the basis that you go in aware it was a top of the line game from another time and definitly shows it's age.

reviewText:
***since the original / unmodded version of the game is heavily bugged, I've played the Action Mod version***

Loved because:

1) Challenging
2 Somewhat slow-paced gameplay ie stealth
3) Able to pick out enemies from afar using sniper rilfer and M4
4) Lush jungle provides cover for self as well as foes
5) Beautiful beach / island settings

Disliked:
1) Being pitted against large group of rocket-welding enemies while I'm stuck with a bloody rifle!  Now this would've been OK if I could continuesly run BUT:
2) I CAN'T RUN FOR MORE THAN 15 seconds. I should be able to choose between gunning VS stealth, but in this game I'm being forced to pick 1 or the other.
3) Extremely cheesy voice acting, especially for Jack and Val
4) Ending. Wow, some anti-climax BS this is.

Overall, it's a lengthy FPS title I'd recommend, and the storyline is pretty engaging considering today's major bulk of shoot-ask-no-questions titles.

reviewText:
A game that is still good, even though it's 11 years old.
Expect to spend > 20 hours on your first playthrough. This game is very difficult, and you have to evolve a different strategy for each firefight. It's a nice mix between open-world and linear, where you can take multiple paths to reach the same goal depending on your playstyle. The story is OK, but I'd recommend getting a quicksave mod; otherwise you'll spend half your time just walking back to the action from the last save point. The AI is a bit derpy, but the game is still challenging.
Also, it runs amazingly well. 1080p 900fps on a 750 Ti, and with graphics to rival any much newer game!
If you're considering getting this game, do. It's regularly reduced to less than £2 in sales.

reviewText: Crytek is a developer that knows how to create near perfect first person shooters. Far Cry is another of those examples from their repertoire. This is some great, solid stuff, despite the bugs and glitches. A game to remember. Far Cry is hard. A true challenge even at the easier difficulty settings. Performance is an issue even for today's hardware standards. The game seems to need a fresh system restart to run at its full potential. There are plenty of bugs and glitches. Some were so major that I was forced to reload a save point several times. The game engine and physics is different than most other games, and this takes a little getting used to. The main character's voice acting is pretty bad. Almost to the point of making it sound like a comedy. For whatever idiotic reason, the game alters the Windows audio settings to its liking without setting them back to their original state. This is extremely annoying. Staying in the subject of sound, do a Google search and you will see the massive amount of sound problems people experience in this game. To access the multiplayer portion of the game, one is forced to register and create an account with Ubisoft, which is absolutely ridiculous. The developers clearly reward players who specialize in stealth and skill shots rather than running and gunning. The atmosphere, mood, and setting are superb; providing a tense and exciting experience almost every second of the game. The tension you will experience is not often produced by other games at this same level. There are many parts where you will be spooked and surprised by what comes around the corner or appears suddenly. It is all done very well. Level design in this game is outstanding. The AI is good, and there is always a challenge. Far Cry is all thriller, no filler.\n\nFar Cry is great.

reviewText: I wish I would have played the original Far Cry when it came out. I played the third Far Cry first, then 4, 2, and now this. I'm having alot of fun playing the original. They're too all-knowing and can snipe with short-to-midrange automatic weapons from across a giant area. This game is much more brutal than most shooters these days. reviewText: So after playing all four far cry games, I can say that this is the worst in the series. The second half of this game is absolutely terrible. The mutants are by far the most annoying and unnecessary enemy in the franchise. The mutants with the rocket launcher take FOREVER to kill, and if you get hit once you are done for, even on the easiest difficulty. The mutants only show up about half way through the game, and everything before that is just fantastic. The game is actually really fun in the beggining and it sets the far cry series up for greatness. If they would have stuck to the same formula that made the first half so great, I would have given this a solid 10/10, but of coarse they had to screw it up.         6/10.

reviewText: There's this strange belief that's been circulating since 2004 that Far Cry is somehow a good game, I know, I know, it's too ludicrous to be true.\nBut it is, and it's still here, that strange, unfathomable belief is still here.\nAnd as I play it, I wonder to myself, why? reviewText:
I have great memories of playing the multiplayer on the original Xbox and Remade Xbox 360 version of this game so I bought this expecting a similar experience and oh my was I dissapointed. It is nothing like the console version and the multiplayer is boring and terrible. What made the multiplayer great on the consoles was the map editor which doesn't exist in this version nor do any custom maps appear online (which is dead, only 1-10 servers with only about 3 or 4 running with a maximum of 8 players if you're lucky) which is the only thing that really made Far Cry multiplayer worth playing.

The campaign I didn't play much of, but it's really typical. I've been waiting for this game to hit 2.49 on sale for a while because a part of me KNEW I was going to be dissapointed and I wasn't wrong. I wouldn't recommend buying this even if it was 99 cents because it's honestly not worth the time in my opinion. The campaign is worth a playthrough I guess but you won't want to play it again.

To get to the point, if you want it for the multiplayer, DO NOT BUY IT because it's basically non-existant. If you want it for the campaign then only buy it on sale because the experience isn't worth 10 dollars.

reviewText:
I don't like to think I am jaded by modern games, but Far Cry is just awful.  The story is terrible and would have been cliched in the 80's, the acting is awful, and the gameplay is boring.  It does have an excellent free-world kind of map but it kind of pulls you along where it wants you to go.

Driving the vehicles in this game is sort of like trying to coax a twitchy squirrel out of a closet while you yourself are mixing uppers and downers.

I would not pay $1.99 for this game.  I wish I had not bought it.

reviewText: Combines hitscan enemies with really long combat distances, quickly lost health that doesn't regenerate*, and AI that are cartoonishly acurate. Pass on this one.\n\n*Medkit-based FPS games only work if properly balanced. Doom, Quake, and F.E.A.R. are games that do it right. In the first two, it's because most enemy attacks can just be dodged. In F.E.A.R., it's because the game lets you a) slo-mo, b) permanently upgrade your health, and c) carry upto 10 medkits. Regenerating health suits games like Far Cry a lot better.

reviewText:
In some ways this is a neat game, It has smart gameplay mechanics and challenging enemy AI (a lot like the marines in Half Life). It is really more a predecessor to Crysis than Far Cry 2 which is almost in a different genre than FC1.

However, I found this game to be more frustrating than entertaining. At first I had a lot of fun because I could use different strategies against the enemies and they were challenging. A lot of the late game enemies are just a chore though. No strategy really works, you just have to play the section ten times until you get lucky and kill them. And since the story is garbage there isn't really much reason to stick with it, it's just painful.

It's extremely difficult, it will make you angry, it will make you cry, you will always die just before you reach the save point because you had to reload at an awkward time. Spare yourself some suffering, play Half Life or Halo 1 instead.

reviewText: Far Cry has somewhat dated now. There are points of it which are still good. Its pretty much non-linear sandbox style maps. You've got your target location, but how you get there is up to you. The use of vehicles is nice (though fairly commonplace in modern games), the locations are nicely rendered and the combat system is okay. The hero is pretty forgettable, just the standard 1980's musclebound ex marine with zero personality. The plot line is somewhat cliched and doesn't really hold much interest. So an average game really, which hasn't stood the test of time too well. My score 6/10

reviewText:
Probably the most overrated game I've ever played in my life.

The Good

It has good physics effects and animations considering the time it was made, that goes for the graphics as well which are quite beautiful and advanced also, it has decent AI, and Jack Carver is a relatively funny main character.

The Bad

It's a ridiculously unbalanced game in terms of difficulty, in the second easiest difficulty you'll find yourself doing several sections again and again and again and again and again (x10) for no other reason other than some enemies are more powerful than they should be, or simply because the game offers you no resources at all, you have your guns, you have your ammo, and you have your luck.

It's also a terribly bland shooter, the only thing you'll be doing in this game is routing through the jungle trying to get the drop on mercenaries, or sometimes weird monsters, sometimes it won't be a jungle, it will be a generic concrete structure called bunker" or "facility" without any real distinction or meaning.

Finally
recommended: it's only there to give sense to the gameplay

reviewText:
I'll review what little bit I managed to play. The intro cutscene seemed to make no sense and it was just a whole lot of random ♥♥♥♥ and then you are taken into a tutorial, and this is where you find out that the controls suck balls.

I won't get too in depth with it but crouching is weird and sometimes it doesn't even do the animation and your screen just jerks down. Sprinting is about 2% faster than your normal speed so all it really does is make you less accurate, does a weird animation and uses up your energy which you need to jump and I think you need it to hold your breath for some reason.

After a little bit of walking you are introduced to the stealth system... Which doesn't work. Press G to throw a rock which is for some strange reason the same button used to throw grenades but that's just a little weird. Now here is why it's broken. There is no delay between an enemy thinking they hear you and them shooting you and this is the best part of the 'stealth' system, I was trying to sneak around and I threw a rock to get some enemies to move and what do they do? Shout 'I've found him!' and they did a 180 and shoot me. So it thinks that it has stealth mechanics but doesn't so your best bet is just shooting everyone but, surprise! sometimes you just die. I don't know how, I thought I had everyone killed but I was being shot so I went and hid and then BAM, dead and remember how sprinting only makes you go 2% faster? yeah have fun running back, oh I'm sorry, taking a leisurely stroll back to where you were to try and kill everyone again.

Animations are just plain lazy, don't look at the machete because you may end up throwing up.

Now, to end this review I will leave you with this. What happens when you decide that it's a terrible game that hardly works? You try to leave, what happens if you try to leave? It crashes and your cursor disappears of screen making it basically impossible to close though I did manage to get my cursor to reappear after locking my account and unlocking it again so there's that.

pros
- I can't wait to uninstall it so that's a plus

cons
-stealth system is broken
-ai is broken
-sometimes you just die because the game decided you should die
-movement system is broken
-game is broken so don't buy it

-1/10

reviewText:
I want to make a huge list of reasons why you shouldn't give them your money for this game.

It all boils down to the game being unplayable and tedious. Combat boils down to you camping a doorway and shooting enemies as they enter your reticle one by one. If you play this like any regular fps you will get killed instantly, more often than not you won't even know where the bots were that shot you to death.

The finale of the third level has you scale a ladder that you'll get stuck on, unable to pull out your gun while a helicopter rains down bullets on you without you being able to run away to dodge or retaliate.

If your idea of a fun fps is watching helplessly as your hp bar go from over 100% to zero in less than a second from an unfair number of overly strong bots (on normal ffs) then this is the game for you.

Skip Far Cry 1 and 2, the first good one is 3.

reviewText:
So firstly i have never played any Far Cry game ever before playing this one in 2015.  This is because i like to play games in order of release and i recently bought a package in the Steam Winter sale 2014 which included Far Cry, Far Cry 2, Far Cry 3 and Far Cry 3 Blood Dragon.  I cant remember how much the package was but it was super cheap.

So this being my first ever Far Cry experience i went in knowing that this was released a long time ago and that it was an older game so didnt expect too much. I haven't really played any other games that i can compare this to within the same time period either so i don't really know what graphics/gameplay mechanics were like back then.

So this game immediatly has terrible graphics in comparison to the film quality graphics of today but i assume they were probably pretty good for 2004 :P

The game is basically mission based unlike Far Cry 4 (which i haven't played but believe is Open World??) so it does feel very linear, meaning you have to go down this set path to these set objectives even though there are occasionally multiple paths to the same place.

The A.I is too sensitive or there is no option to sneak in this game since they appear to 'hear' you from what would seem well out of hearing range.  The A.I can 'hear' you through walls of buildings, they can see you and shoot you through buildings or tents.

The health in this game is very very badly balanced with the enemies/difficulty too.  Since this game has no achievements i thought to myself 'i'll play on the easiest difficulty just so i can enjoy the game and walk through it no problem' LOL! Yeah so i somehow manage to take two bullets and my entire Armor and Health are basically depleted on the easiest difficulty.

This just makes it too much of a pain to complete the missions for me and having put in what i believe to be a decent amount of effort and time trying to finish the game, i just can't bring myself to finish it because im dying too easily, the story isnt too interesting, the voice acting and all the cheesy lines are terrible and im just generally not enjoying playing it.

So from me this game on its own i wouldn't reccomend but i will be playing Far Cry 2 next and so on, so maybe as a part of the Far Cry package it wouldn't be as bad.

reviewText:
-Updated 1/28/15-

How to begin this review? Firstly, thank you to Rinon for buying me this game.

Now with the pleasantries over with I can go into the meat of the review. Yes, this is an eleven year old game, but even on my rather decent gaming rig I was getting graphical artifacts, crashes and not even being able to play the game for what little I played. I purchased this game retail when it came out in '04, and my memories were true. Crytek make pretty engines, but horrible games. With enemies that can instakill you on moderate difficulty before you are within visual range of them, enemies that have models that pop in out of nowhere, and constant, frustrating artifacts the game was unplayable for me on each and every setting. Audio was a joke, as my headphones could just barely pick up voices and/or sounds even when at the maximum volume.

Normally my OCD requires me to play each and every game in a series, but for now - I am skipping over to Far Cry 2. Your results with this game might vary, but in my opinion - do not get your hopes up.

-Update 1/28/15-
Another three hours of wrangling with the game and all I ended up with was a pair of BSODs, an overheated GPU, and a full on crash that forced me into safe mode. I hate to do this but I am going to have to urge others not to purchase this game, it could damage modern hardware if my results are any proof.
voteText: 6 of 15 people (40%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Having no nostalgia or rose tinted glasses for this game I can firmly say this game dousn't really stand well against the test of time. When it was new and innovative Im sure people looked at it like it was great. I can firmly say that this game isn't that great. Its definetly dated and in relative to game design of more recent its just inferior.

Is it fun? Yeah, but more often than not I found I was having fun only to just die with no real idea who or what killed me or how. Then being forced to reload and play what might be a lengthy part of the game which ultimately undoes any fun it was the first time.  Also the fun is to few and far in between.

Gameplay genereally revolves around getting from A to B and killing everyone who gets in the way in between. Sometimes B is an objective or a bomb you need to blow something up which means you need to go get the bomb then back track usually. Theres vehicles peppering the game that add some variety aswell as a myriad of weapons. Some of which are quite a bit more usefull than others. Theres a combination of both semi-open world maps and corridors though the game is best when outside in a semi-open world map where the AI is best to play against

The AI has issues. They do that old thing games used to do (and bad games still do) where enemies will snap to you and shoot immediatly if you so much as poke your head out while they are alerted, while some other times they won't even be looking the right way or they will just stare at you. Or if your driving on a boat at full speed they will still be hitting you no matter how fast you are going. Its compounded by the fact tracers dont necesarrily follow where the bullets are traveling or hitting (which is especially common in older and cheaper games) so it can be hard knowing exactly if your hitting or what your getting hit by (next to no problem when your on foot shooting though when using mounted weapons it is). Another issue is that in close quarters the AI shoots so accurate and fast that with guns one guy can pretty much take most your armor and health away. Which while you did everything right, all it took was one rogue guy and a bad checkpoint and now your saved with less than 50% hp and no armor.  Luckily theres usually not much terraferma between health and armor, though sometimes it can be quite a drag to get to them. Ironically regenerating HP would actually make this game more enjoyable especially with how difficult it is and how little damage you can take anyway. An issue I have found is that RPG guys are way to often. RPG wielding enemies will shoot from ridiculous ranges at you, fortunately RPGS travel pretty slow but its still annoying especially with the blast radius. Another point about explosions, they are very inconsistant. If you shoot a rocket anywhere near a vehicle (such as using the jeep mounted RPG to blow guys out of cover) and even relatively far away you will 1 shot kill yourself. I think I played this on challenging, so I advise playing it on normal or easy, unfortuantely on easy and normal the AI are pretty stupid and can just barely hit you with my testing. Yep, its one of those games where instead of making the AI linearly more challenging its basically a cliff of difficulty.

The mutants are an interesting addition but have so little variety that theres only like 3 or 4 diffrent ones and compared to the humans they arn't fun to fight due to little or no tactics but they can kill you with incredible ease in some cases. But by the end of the game theres a over reliance on mutants with rocket launchers to make it difficult and it really stops being interesting by then. They soak up so much damage that its easier in most cases to just go past or around them and since you move so slow it can be hard to dodge away from them and their spalsh damage which again is the reason I prefer not to fight them.

It gets worse when your going up against armored guys who will soak up anything short of a headshot (So thats where Far Cry 2 got that design idea from...) And the inconsistant nature of the AI just gets worse. Some bushes that should conceal you the AI might see right through and get alerted and shoot you, while the opposite also happens. Sometimes AI decides they want to dump a magazine and hit you with a good number of rounds while at medium distance.

Though for all its bad, the AI does try basic tactics such as sneaking and they do exhibit independant like thinking capabilities. Instead of the game saying you are here (which does happen) the AI will exhibit cases where NPCs will search for you and while one may find you the others wont be informed of your location in the world until they learn of it. Or atleast thats what it seems like, its not as good as Far Cry 2 and both pale in comparison to Arma and mil sim games. The mutants don't seem to do much in terms of tactics though.

Saving is not very good. Unlike past games like Doom or HL1 saves are check point based and not very good. Sometimes they are to far between and with no capability to save yourself you are at the will of the save system. So a shoot out your having trouble getting past means you have to reload and get back to the fight just to try to get past it.  These days check points and auto saving is much better than this but this is far from that and really needed a manual save.

Vehicles pepper the world and levels and offer variance to the gameplay which is especially nice with the boat levels as they are some of the largest levels and offer the most tactical choices aswell as looking the best. I really like the reflection in water when used in games. Unfortunately land mass dousn't usually get reflected due to a glitch in the steam version regarding modern OS compatability if I remember.

Compatability wise, the game is just barely there. Im honestly surprised the game actually works and dousn't crash or have many issues. Its advisable to download a fan made updated (1.41) or some other mods that make it so enemies dont see through buildings (primarily tents and shacks how the f*ck did that get through QA?) aswell as some address other glitches or add stuff to the game. If you can help it, don't buy the Steam version but instead buy the GOG version.  Sometimes when I try to close the game the game will give a black screen and keep running. As I said it just barely works.

The story is a throw away. Its like the John Carmack quote. The story here is just ultimately to give you a reason to go kill and shoot people and its pretty stupid and goofy but not entertaining on its own or anything worth mention.

The GOG version costs the same and is more open aswell comes from a truly free (freedom wise) service in terms of DRM.

I wouldn't recommend this game unless you are heavy into classic FPS games or unless your looking for a decent but hard FPS game. If you just want a good or great game this just isn't it, Far Cry 2 is better in some aspects especially gameplay though so I would recomend that one more so. If you really care about the Far Cry series your not missing much if anything at all. If you do want to play it don't put it above normal and maybe even easy and it might even be worth it to stop playing the game before you get to the latter levels as story wise and mechanics wise your missing nothing. Best parts are when your in an open area and fighting humans anyway. Also the final fight is intensly difficult for what feels like all the wrong reasons. Its all the worst parts of the game put together to just make it hard. So theres nothing your going to miss if you stop playing before the final mission or around the time the game turns more into a corridor shootery type game.

reviewText: However groundbreaking this game may have been when it came out, its successors have only served to highlight some deep flaws. The stealth - a core element of the gameplay - is often a joke thanks to inconsistent line of sight and terrain mechanics, while the combat is awkward and overly difficult due to stiff controls and animations. reviewText:
Is it past 2005? Yes? Don't buy this game.

Although it was considered ground breaking and innovative in it's time, it has not aged well and is now mediocre at best plus a BUNCH of bugs and a ridiculous amount of difficulty. I just finished the campaign and I will not be playing the game at all after that. I simply wanted to play through it so I could say I played the whole series.

One of my main gripes with this game is the way the AI can perfectly shoot you through walls. I'm all for bullets going through tents (it seems the buildings in the compounds are made of the same material as tents or whatever) and all but it should be a random chest-height spray that you can easily avoid. Not perfect pinpoint aim right at you no matter where you move or how you attempt to dodge. Couple that with the fact that you can easily die in 3-4 bullets, and you get some really, really frustrating gameplay.

I know this was made in 2004 and I gave it the benefit of the doubt in that regard. But, even in 2004, I expect to be safe from outside gunfire when I enter a building. Also, another thing that frustrated me were the stairs. They are extremely broken, mostly the metal ones, and I often got stuck and had to spam prone/jump to get out of the glitched area. This could often be a problem when in a fight as you can't really walk up these stairs without glitch-hopping and jumpinh around.

Lastly, the games story was really bland. For almost the whole thing, but especially at the end I was questioning why I was doing what I was doing.

SPOILERS AHEAD

I want to take this time to rant about the end of the game and how stupid/confusing it was. So for those of you who have played it, when you blow up the nuke, all of a sudden you are now captured in a helicopter with the main bad guy? It made no sense to me. I thought the game was going to end with that nuke but nope instead you get put into a typical fight for survival where you are striped of all weapons and equipment hooray! And then the end where you got to kill Doyle? Was his betrayal not the most obvious thing or what. I thought literally from the moment he first contacted me that he was going to end up being a bad guy in the end. Really predictable and boring story coupled with bad voice acting to boot, I'm just glad it's over.

reviewText:
While the game itself stands up to the test of time, the compatability issues are very frustrating on many modern computers.

First off, the steam version of this game has an old bug present which allows AI to see and shoot through certain walls. This can be fixed by modding the game or downloading a fix patch. However, this bug was fixed early on when this game first came out, and therefore there isn't an excuse for it to be present on this Steam version.

The main problem, however, is the fact that in my experience, certain load points always crash the game. I have been unable to fix this problem.

Overall, not recommended unless you are confident you can make the game work on your system.

reviewText:
I'm sure this was great in 2004, but I'm judging it both in 2015 (when you have better shooters to spend your time on) and compared to what else was available in 2004 (such as Half-Life 2).  It still looks pretty good, but the game mechanics have not aged well.  There's no plot connection between the various Far Cry games, you might as well spend your time on a later and better designed Far Cry.

The plot, characters and voice acting are sub-par.  I get it's supposed to be a parody, but it's the sort of lazy parody that becomes what it's parodying.  You're a guy with a gruff voice who will kill everybody on an island because some stranger on a cell phone says so. Finding your probably kidnapped girlfriend seems secondary.

Combat can be brutal, even at a modest difficulty level, and you usually want to avoid a stand up fight (this is a positive to me).  You're usually heavily outnumbered and don't have a lot of health.  However, the game's combatants fall to typical overpowered FPS tactics like sniping, head shots and vehicles.

This could have been mitigated by a good stealth system, but I found it hard to predict when and what would cause me to be spotted.  Sometimes I would be sneaking inside a building and shot through the walls.  Other times I could head shot a guard in the middle of an enemy camp and nobody seemed to notice.  Maybe they're all just super chill nilhists?  The inability to save the game other than at predetermined save points made dying after spending much time sneaking around particularly frustrating.

The breaking point for me was a map in a dark cave.  Grey soldiers against grey walls that I can't see, but they seem to see me just fine.  I'd sneak along only to hear who's there" followed by muzzle flashes in my face.

Maybe the game gets awesome later
date: but I'm not sticking around to find out.  I'm skipping ahead to Far Cry 2."

reviewText:
Project Far Cry, also known as Far Cry is the original title in a franchise which has been successful for a decade now. Its setting has evolved a great deal since its inception. I'm not sure if Ubisoft was aware of what they were creating back in 2004 when Far Cry was released but I believe it's safe to assume most gamers have had a fair amount of enjoyment from the series.

Far Cry was set on the world's most tropical island with crystal clear waters and a bright, vibrant, lush green bushes and rainforests. The setting of this game really is something you would dream of and is quite interesting in this respect - the environment is beautiful.

As this game was released along-side to id software's Doom 3, Far Cry claimed via marketing to be so much better in every way. Unfortunately Far Cry was heavily over-rated by the media of the day and provides little to cater for new technologies and physics at its time. Doom 3 may have had serious hardware problems in its day but it has aged gracefully and the same cannot be said for Far Cry. I actually found Far Cry loves to randomly crash with critical errors, so naturally my judgement is that Far Cry was never completed - which might be the reason for my gripes with this game.

I loved the weaponry - however limited, but especially the machine gun - for such a limited time of which I had. I enjoyed the method of mission delivery and how missions are carried out and the games general mechanics. The game does however feature broken physics, a disinteresting and mediocre story and really bad AI.

As for the physics, it was quite simple that I expect not to be shot inside of a building from the outside with bullets and I would expect to never kill people outside in that situation - but honestly, it seems there's a first for everything. The story and protagonist were quite bad but I won't spoil any - I actually found more interest in the companion unlocked late in the game. The bad AI, well I wouldn't say the AI themselves are bad because I saw them perform some interesting things including team leaders giving their forces hand gestures - I'll admit that surprised me. What I mean is that the enemies can take you out from miles away with a rocket and there's nothing you can do about this - but when you get a rocket launcher you don't have the same accuracy. It seems there's some serious aimbot action happening here and I disapprove.

My only other gripe is related to the realism of the tropical island setting - where the story progresses to include monsters and mutants and some seriously lame elements. Aside from this they basically have one-hit kills and take a lot of ammunition to take down so the difficulty fluctuates significantly and most people will give up on this game.

To be fair I didn't use all the games mechanics, I didn't learn where enemies are exactly, so there's definitely a way through this game with ease but not without experience. I suppose I never used these features due to the control setup, and I just shifted the controls to my liking.

Overall, I believe this game is highly over-rated and those calling this a classic are only doing it for nostalgia. It's a great game on the outside, nice and fun, but once you begin progressing you'll realise that it's not an amazing game with huge technological advances such to what everybody of the time were fed by the media, but it's nothing more than incomplete and broken.

I'm glad its sequel was an improvement in every way, really.

reviewText:
If I had played this game when it first released 10 years ago, maybe I wouldn't have had such a big problem getting through this game. There are so many issues I had with the game that made the experience unpleasant, and a chore to get through.

The guns are crap, in my opinion. Every single one of them. Most of them have pretty crappy accuracy, do little damage, and even point blank range with the shotgun takes a few shots to kill almost everything. The only gun worth anything was the sniper rifle, but only when prone. Otherwise, good luck with the broad side of that barn.
The AI is stupid. They were shooting me with pinpoint accuracy through a wall at one point. Through a WALL. What the hell is up with this?
Random guys with RPGs that are sometimes near impossible to spot can nearly one shot you if you're not paying attention.
Your movement speed is horrid. You pretty much move as fast as a snail, and the sprinting is only a small fraction faster. Some of these levels are HUGE, and if you can't find any sort of vehicle, or the game doesn't give you one, well, god help you.
This game is HARD as Hell. In the later levels, there are so many baddies in each swarm, some extremely powerful with way too much health, several of them at the same time, that I don't think its likely to be possible without cheating. I'm not a hardcore gamer, and I don't like this level of difficulty. I was playing on Normal...not even one of the harder difficulties, but I still couldn't do it.
I didn't really find the story all that interesting. For me, it was just kind of there, behind the swarms and swarms of enemies.
To me, the game just feels unbalanced, unpolished, even broken in some ways.
This game had a few redeeming qualities though
Some of the levels are pretty open, which allow for multiple approaches to getting past or through the enemies.
Each level was unique and for the most part well-executed. Some areas are huge. The indoor level layout was pretty linear but this wasn't a problem for me because I grew up playing linear games like this.
Actually, I think that's about it, off the top of my head. I didn't absolutely hate this game but I did not enjoy my experience with it. Unless you're a hardcore gamer who loves challenge, I would pass this up and try the other games in this series instead, or if you got the entire collection really cheap like I did, just don't bother with this one and start with Far Cry 2. This game is just too hard.

5/10
Meh

reviewText:
Far Cry 1 is a game that has aged surprisingly well.

Especially from a graphics standpoint.

It won't make Nvidia enthusiasts salivate. But it means that Crytek was able to churn out enough polygons and sfx to make it actually passable in the critical eyes of today's players.
That is high praise, technically speaking, since 90s and early 2000s FPS usually look like something that came out the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ of Far Cry's Trigen Baboons.
So maybe its historical legacy will be that - the first modern 3d game that has aged visually well.
It's also very easy on modern gfx cards. It seems my GTX 460 breaks more sweat when rendering pixeled hipster games.

So how is Far Cry in terms of play?
It's really basic:
A beautiful caribbean island, a shlocky story.
You're shooting bad guys with guns, take their guns and run around, quite a lot actually.
The most shocking features are a *omygawd* stamina bar, being able to *gasp* drop down and shoot from a prone position and *sweetjeezustheresmoar* shooting through many types of walls.
This is all implemented solidly.

More of FC's strengths: AI behaviour is great. Sound fx are fine.

Some features were run-of-the-mill at the time, but may be received controversially today:
No automatic bumwiping er... health regeneration I mean. Have fun backtracking!
No excessive exposition.
No military propaganda.
And...caveat millenials ... NO QUICKSAVING. The game autosaves for you, rather fairly, I'd have to say.
This might be a dealbreaker for many, but it actually works.


If you're a fan of basic FPS, you can play Far Cry without blushing.
It's alright. No shame in liking meat and potatoes, chart music or missionary,

All others, pass. There's just too little substance.


VERDICT
Dr. Krieger's ethics commision approves 2,5 out of 5 specimen.
Decent, basic, passable - for FPS fans.

reviewText:
2004 was an exciting year for gaming, and this was one of that year's flagship titles.  I skipped over it until 2014, when I picked up all the Far Cry games in a set.  I decided to play them in order.

This game did not age well.  It runs very poorly on modern hardware.  Every aspect of its design is an example of a mistake we've learned from.  It felt like such a chore, that I gave up about 60% of the way through and skimmed through an LP instead of finishing it myself.  I've never done that for any game before.

I can't recommend this, unless you're playing it for nostalgia or a bit of education in gaming history.

reviewText:
Undoubtedly a game that was impressive upon release, today, it finds itself done wrong by an overwhelmingly mediocre story, inconsistent difficulty, and general tedium, which leads me to not be able to recommend this game.

Certainly, it wasn't immediately terrible, the early sections of the game, bar one helicopter sequence, have you traversing an island that would clearly have faint echoes in 2007's legendary Crysis, with impressive foilage and shooting action for 2004.  But as the game progresses, the enemies get dumber, the hallways get longer, and the game starts to wear on you.  The shooting never really evolves past hopping around the mutated enemies, or spraying hot lead in the general direction of humanoid ones.

The story itself seems disinterested with you and your actions, with the closing third of the game feeling slightly tacked on just to pad length.  It's never really quite sure if it wants to be a parody of Rambo-style B movies from the 70s, or a completely serious and dull tale of the multitalented cardboard box that serves as the protagonists's personality.  Also in this final third, the difficulty reaches a cliff the likes of which had me reaching for Dwarf Fortress for relief.  The first of two final bosses proves to be a painful experience even on Normal difficulty, but far too easy on the easiest one.  There is a section nearly directly preceding it that has you running through the jungle from the mutants, where it's basically luck if you get hit or not by them, allowing you to progress.

I may have gotten this game for very cheap, and even with no expectations, I came out feeling disappointed.

reviewText:
One of my least favorite games I've ever played.

I played this game because I anticipate buying a new computer and getting the next-gen Far Cry games (3 and 4) so I decided to play the first and second games to see how they may compare.

After playing this, I already know this is my least favorite out of the entire series.

- Gunplay in this game is bland and repetitive. There's no variation in the combat whatsoever and after an hour or so it becomes the most boring thing ever. Plus it's very inconsistent, you can one-hit a guard with the suppressed MP5K then a minute later you can mow down the same type of guard with the M4 and kill him after half the mag is in his chest.

- The NPCs are the worst. Seriously, being able to shoot through the walls at you in multiple situations after one of them has seen you is the worst. It makes so many parts of the game almost impossible. Their repetitive, bland voices make you want to cry. After about 30 minutes of hearing I'm gonna shoot your face off!" and "I'm gonna lay down the smackdown!" I already wanted to gag myself with a spoon.

- Speaking of voice acting
date: every person in this game with a speaking part makes me cringe. Especially the main character
recommended: his Nukem-esque voice and cliche one-liners become super annoying after the first moments of hearing him.\n\n- Some parts of this game are so hard they may even seem impossible (even on normal difficulty). The NPCs have some undying blood-lust rage even on the easiest setting. You should be able to have fun and rush whomever on the easiest difficulty but you can't do that and it's overkill in my opinion. Some parts like the mini-boss against Crowe on the sinking ship
hoursPlayed: where you have NO supplies around you and the game doesn't allow you to shoot while submirged in water so it's super difficult to get a shot off especially while Crowe is mowing you down with his LMG.\n\n- Some things
voteText: like the ability to look at a situation and decide where to go and what kind of way to take it (Like run-and-gun vs. a stealth approach.) made me happy early on
helpfulPercent: but later on it turned into "Okay
votesHelpful: either turn right and get shot at or turn left and get shot at. Your choice bro.".\n\n- The story is strictly linear and boring. It's pretty predictable and the complete change in the enemies in the middle of the game was terrible. Especially since the "Trigens" are one-hit kill enemies (with no armour). It seems like a cool story at first and it looks like it'll end up being a pretty nice
votesTotal: open game but it's just so straight forward and linear. It's honestly super disapointing.\n\nOverall

reviewText: This is one of those instances where the last few hours or so ruined the complete rest of the game for me.  Started off with some great shooting in some nicely wide-open levels, ended with a bunch of annoying NPC-escorting, turret-operating, and a final confrontation inside a volcano where you'll repetedly get shot to pieces by snipers you couldn't possibly see through all the fog.\n\nI really ought to go play through this again, maybe throw a few mods on it.  But until then, these are my last memories of this game.  And they aren't good ones.

reviewText:
3/10
An utterly frustrating, disappointing and enraging game.
Worthless minimap, no world map at all, no manageable inventory, no character progression, 7 weapons in all of the game (including a useless machete, a pistol only the weakest NPC's use and a rocket launcher you will never need).
Also just one piece of repeatable armor and only one occasional way of healing which you can't even carry around.
The story must have taken them like 1 hour to write, seeing that you are just thrown intothe thick of it and later on (unlike later far cry 3) you aren't told the story either.
Insane damage from even the most simple of enemies even in medium difficulty that I played, regardless of their positioning (hit you through cover and with their sight obscured by objects), INSANE sight range for some enemies (last case of that I encountered was getting shot at ACCURATELY by RPG's from a distance so big that I couldnt even spot the enemy with my binoculars). No valuable long term stealthy gameplay either, due to the aforementioned factors, as well as the enemy being able to hear your movement on a certain radius (this is waht makes the machete totally worthless, seeing that the hearing radius is grater than your mellee range) and no silenced weapons being available (not even the sniper rifle, which will triger NPC alertness no matter out of what range you are shooting. You as a player are OFC unable to hear the enemy snipers shots).
No replay value what so ever seeing that there is no RPG immersion, no decisions to make, no nothing. The same story over and over again.
This game is a bit like COD, only that you have insane NPC's instead of noob kids ruining the game. Hell, some NPC's are even campers!
On the other hand to get through some places you will have to start thinking, meaning that the progression isn't obvious or given to you by the game, even the descriptionless objectives and close to useless minimap add to this.
Finally, to be fair, I have to admit that I didn't try multiplayer, which, if good, could at some points to the game (in case you still find anyone playing vanilla Far Cry, that is).

reviewText:
The short version: bland selection of weapons, laughable stealth mechanics, and inflated, artless difficulty in a pathetic bid for cred as a tactical shooter. A worthless non-plot even by video game standards, to the point where the usual juvenile BS barely even registers as campy or offensive. No, Steam, I don't recommend this game.

The long version:

The weapons are boring. You have your choice of (thus far at least, I'm not finishing this thing): assault rifle, two SMGs (one useless), rocket launcher, sniper rifle (rare), shotgun, pistol (useless), and machete (useless). Obviously not every game needs a sweeping array of whimsical fantasy weaponry, but a big part of shooters for me is bonding with my favorite guns and none of these dull gray slabs cut it.

The story is not worth a turd. The player character has bad cringey voice acting, no real qualities but a sort of flat, lazy sarcasm, and no will of his own, only taking orders from a voice on his phone. A female partner is teased early on but shows up in a cutscene tackily emulating Ursula Andress in Dr. No only to disappear again for hours.

The graphics are nice for their time. Vegetation--bushes, grass, vines, leaves--was (and often still is) one of polygonal graphics' big weaknesses; setting a shooter on a tropical island must have seemed like an impossible dream to many. And yet the jungle gets monotonous fast. You can (literally) go off the beaten path and explore around and sometimes find alternate paths through a level, but doing so never feels worth it because you can't actually sneak past enemies (more about that later). Indoor levels don't even have graphics or exploration going for them. Cement fortresses filled with catwalks and computer equipment. Sewers and tunnels with no sign of vermin and that don't seem particularly dirty or smelly. Blah.

Movement is awkward. You can't go very fast, even when sprinting, which depletes a stamina bar and broadcasts your location to every enemy within a city-block radius. You'll be spending most of the game semi-stealthed in a crouch position by holding CTRL but even then enemies can easily spot you. Interacting with the environment sucks too, you have to be flat up against and aiming perpendicular to and directly at whatever it is you want to pick up or use. So doing anything actually badass, like using a keycard to jump through a door in the middle of a firefight, or killing a dude, grabbing his gun, and killing the next dude with it, is next to impossible. Oh, and the ladders! I forgot about the ladders. The suckitude of ladders in this game doesn't even deserve explanation. ♥♥♥♥ you, ladders!

Far Cry is also, as others have noted, too goddam hard. Enemies a mile away can detect you and kill you to death in under a second. There's also godawful pop-in that prevents you from seeing distant enemies. Frequently you'll die suddenly from someone you can't even see or hear. Once, I discovered this was because the enemy was headshotting me FROM THE OTHER SIDE OF AN OPAQUE TENT. The stealth mechanics, with the exception of the night vision, are next to useless, and it even features that ultimate early-2000s PC FPS frivolity, the lean" movement bound to Q and E. The best you can hope for with stealth is to position yourself for a firefight and maybe take out the first one or two guys (often of ten or more
date: mind you) in an area. You have radar and can use the binoculars to mark enemies on it
recommended: but doing so is a false sense of security because it usually won't see everyone
hoursPlayed: and those one or two guys it didn't catch will get the drop on you. And even successfully being stealthy isn't the best choice
voteText: because guys you sneak past will come running to find you next time they hear gunshots. You can't hear enemies coming because they make no footstep noises; if you're lucky you'll hear some stupid taunt like "I'm-a gonna gun yer face to helllllll!" or whatever but those voice clips always sound closer than they really are. This is all on the default "Medium" difficulty

reviewText: This game started out fun and interesting but has quickly turned into a game that I very sincerely regret buying. It was a complete waste of money, and I rarely say that about any game. The only reason I am still playing it at this point is because I have a thing about finishing all of my games. It looks good enough for a 2004 title, the voice acting is bad but forgiveable (nothing can be worse than Resident Evil), and the maps are large and sem-open, but that's where it ends. The stairs and ladders are bugged, the AI Balance function isn't actually a functional function, the enemies are OP and can one-shot you from clear across the map, the stealth mechanics don't work, you can't exit the game without it crashing on you, and probably the worst thing: there is NO manual save. Well, there is, but it's way too much of a pain in the ♥♥♥ to do. It involves altering some game files in developer mode. So yeah. The game auto-saves at the worst possible locations, so I found myself having to cover the same expanses of map and doing the same things over and over and over and over again until I got lucky enough to make it to the next checkpoint. Like I said, if it weren't for this thing I have about finishing my games, I'd give up on this piece of junk.

reviewText:
Story:
Ehhhhhh...ewwww.....really Ubisoft? Another mad scientist with his attempt at making super humans, but it goes wrong and then they go rogue. Great...I really need another game where this happens. OH I'm trying to escape the island!?! Why don't I just use one of the last 17 boats I got into to escape?!? NO I have to use them to go from small island to other small island. NEVER back to the mainland. I mean I got here on a sailboat I think  could make it back with a tank of gas so don't give me that excuse. And then there is Valarie...screw Valarie. I don't care! I have no idea who she is! There was no character development. I mean I love a game where you get chucked into it and you have to figure everything out, but when I'm told to go save someone whom I have no relation to? That's just bad design. It ceases to become a game and it becomes work. Maybe they should give me an incentive to go after her? Make me want to save her not just tell me to in order to justify their game and provide an excuse for, frankly, sub-par level design.

Playability:
This is where the game took a turn for the worse, I mean really worse. The AI was one of the most disgusting things in the world. Think Sonic '06 level of broken. I mean almost completely broken. The so called “stealth” would never work. You could be 100 yards away, prone in a bush, and you would hear “There he is!” and start getting shot at. They constantly “see” you before you even enter the room, and once I was spotted while prone INSIDE A VENTALATION SHAFT! All this combined with constantly being shot through walls or the guy INSIDE the garage but lit you up from a car's turret regardless makes the game most aggravating. Another moment was when you were told that the entrance to the boat was a hole in the side. Well guess what? They didn't mean the big obvious hole in the side. It was a small entrance near the bow of the ship. It took me about 10 minutes of jumping against a wall before I thought “Maybe the hole isn't this hole? Maybe there is another? Maybe Ubisoft pulled a fast one on me?” Even with all of these pitfalls, by no means is it a difficult game. Just repetitive and annoying. So many things were included in the game to make it longer. It felt like an ordeal, so when you beat it you wouldn't want to have to go through it again providing the illusion of difficulty. They used level design to act as a difficulty supplement, not make it actually hard. Honestly, when I see a game company do this they lose a lot of respect.

Level Design:
“Open world” another great joke from Ubisoft. They obviously think open-world means “go here, then here, then here, then big battle, then go here.” They were extremely linear and after awhile just left a weird taste in you mouth like you get after drinking milk and then not drinking anything else for an hour. It became “Great...another building” and there was a lot of “Here I am shooting a near-identical person in a near-identical situation as the last few hundred.” It just wears you out. The addition of checkpoints just proves my point. You cant have checkpoints in a non-linear game. They just made the game even more linear. The only way you can save is if you go along the per-defined path layed out for you. Additionally, there are no side quests. I'm not saying that side quests are a mandatory feature of every game, but in an open world game, they certainly are.

Graphics:
Rather good, but honestly Counter-strike source and Metal Gear Solid 3 had better graphics and they were released in the same year. One redeeming feature was the draw distance in Cry-engine is vast which required little loading time.

Overall:
“A glorified tech demo, don't bother unless you're curious about how advanced graphics could get back in 2004.” -Crisis from Steam
It made me laugh, and I agreed so I figured I'd re-post it.

reviewText:
There are two types of challenging games. The first type is the one where you get killed a lot because you ♥♥♥♥ed up, and you know you ♥♥♥♥ed up. Super Meat Boy. Dark Souls. Then there's the type of game where you get killed a lot because the design is cheap and unfair. That's Far Cry.

Far Cry is an absolute chore to play through. You will need to persist through piles of inexplicably bad design and an ungodly amount of unfair deaths to trial-and-error your way to the best tactic. Get Lucky or Die Quickly. It's finishable, but why would you want to? It's just not fun.

SO HERE'S HOW IT WORKS.

The game uses a checkpoint system, so quicksaving through a map when things are going well is not an option. You usually have the choice of fighting or using stealth. If you use stealth, be prepared to move VERY SLOWLY while crouched or prone, which saps the joy out of staying hidden. It can take a long time to traverse the map like this, and since enemies have such keen perception, you'll probably get spotted most times anyway. Not keen in the fair sense though. Keen because they can hear your footsteps from hundreds of feet away behind a building, or one of them can see you through the dense foliage you're hiding in because your shirt is so ♥♥♥♥ING RED, and they can all shoot through solid objects with unerring accuracy because they all have x-ray vision. Getting spotted after a 5-10 minute stealth creep and reloading a checkpoint isn't fun.

So the alternative? Run and gun. This is a mixed proposition. It can feel good when it works, and the combat is nice and responsive, but you will get flanked and taken down constantly. Far Cry employs a health pack system with very few health packs, so again, 10-minute checkpoints need to be played over and over again because it just takes that one ♥♥♥♥ing guy out of the 25 you fought to get around your flank and it's die, redo. It reminded me a lot of Call of Duty 2 on Veteran mode (anybody?), but I was playing on normal.

Here's how the ROCKET LAUNCHERS work. Mercs and mutants with rocket launchers fire them in such quick succession that if any one of them gets the bead on you, you are literally too slow to outrun them. If you DO stay ahead of the rocket stream, the smoke keeps you perpetually blind while the screen shakes, thus making it IMPOSSIBLE for you to fight back. Rocket launcher guys are usually a half-mile away as well, so die, reload. It's like playing Doom 2, except that you can only take one hit before death and the bad guys can shoot through walls and also, you have crazy glue on the bottom of your shoes. Not fun!

Die, reload. You will die a lot. Maybe you'll get a checkpoint, but it will be in the middle of combat. Remember that rocket stream I just told you about? I got a checkpoint once while there were two rockets in the air sailing towards me. Die, reload, die, reload, die, reload, can't escape, restart entire mission. Thanks Far Cry!

The combat is functional in the corridor sections, but in wide-open spaces, it's just a matter of exploiting the AI in cheap ways and engaging from long distances to avoid any real conflict. The best strategy: go for headshots while the AI is non-reactive to your presence and they're just standing there like target dummies. Or wait for them to get caught in a ridiculous movement loop and time your shot. Not fun!

Your health, even on easy mode, is laughably minimal, and the hardcore difficulty of the game is mostly caused by the AI's impossibly keen sense, unerring accuracy, and your ability to absorb about 2 1/2 bullets before dying. Not fun!

I got halfway through the game and realized I had no idea what was going on or why this dude was on this island or why the voice actors talk like they're not taking their jobs or this game seriously at all.

I wouldn't either, the script and story are a pile of feces.

At one point a mercenary shouts, YOU'RE GONNA WISH YOU WERE DEAD!" -- while he's unloading his machine gun at me. Try to make sense of that.

Spoiler alert: there are mutants
date:
and they look like rejected Quake 2 designs.

This entire game has no idea what its identity or focus is.

You can't even blame 2004 for this. Half-Life 2 came out a few months later and was perfect in every way
recommended:
while Doom 3 even succeeds in topping this game with its focused combat and sharp atmosphere. And Doom 3 sucked.

I would rather contract malaria than play this game again. I guess I'll play the sequel.


3.5/10"

reviewText: This would of been a great game to get in 2004, but now ten years later; this game is boring, has seemingly repetitive gameplay with small tweaks in the objectives you are doing, terrible voice acting but suprisingly good audio quality, and obviously this game has the graphics of a game from 2004, like it should.  I'm not entirely hating on this game since it is old, and I'm sure that this was a great title to play in 2004, but this game just simply isn't worth $10 as of 2014 and beyond.  The only reason that I own this game is because of the Steam Summer Sale of 2014 and I bought the Far Cry Franchise Pack, which including; this game, Far Cry 2, Far Cry 3, and Far Cry 3: Blood Dragon.\n\nThe only reason I would suggest getting this game is in the Far Cry Franchise Pack, but if you already have the other Far Cry games, don't bother buying this title.

reviewText: I never thought I would play a game where the console version is infinitely better than the PC version, but if ever there were such a thing, this is perhaps the most extreme case.  This might be the worst game I have ever played.  The graphics and draw distance are nice considering the times (tho I found the texture pop-up annoying), the gunplay is acceptable, but these were clearly the only things that any thought was put into; the obnoxious, flaky AI consists mostly of wall-hacking aimbots (in fact, a user had to create an unofficial patch to fix bots being able to see and shoot through certain surfaces, which made the game unplayable for me.  To be clear, that's a USER doing the DEVELOPER's job for FREE), and combined with an archaic checkpoint system with no manual or quick-save, you can anticipate spending hours of your life replaying the same 10mins between checkpoints overandoverandoverandover sluggishly advancing through the occasionally engaging maps.  The game seems to encourage or give the option of stealth at times, but with AI like this, I gave that up by the third level.  Some games are frusturating but highly rewarding, but I never even felt any sense of reward overcoming each obnoxious challenge"

reviewText:
Most of the comments on the other reviews are accurate. The AI is ridiculous. With the large areas you play in, you'll be getting hit by someone you can't even see!

I also found that the game frequently crashed on me. Not worth picking up. I'm sure it was a ground breaking game in its time, but it doesn't really hold up. I picked it up for very little during a Steam sale, as I'd heard a lot about the Far Cry series, but had never owned a computer capable of playing the more recent sequels.

Also, the 6 hours that it says I've played is actually longer as in order to try to fix the game crashing bug, I deleted and tried reinstalling. Nope. Still crashes.

reviewText:
Nothing like a bug (known since launch) that corrupts your save games to be unloadable, rendering the game that autosaves only to be unplayable.  Their solution?  Use the console and cheat your way to the next checkpoint, oh, and you have to modify your shortcut to put the game in developer mode to do so.  Add the random crashes to desktop and we have a real winner.

I'd expect nothing less from Ubisoft, a company that I'm adding to the list of things to boycott for total suckage.  Between their completely idiotic DRM attempts and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ games that just fail to work I'm done.

Assassin's Creed, you say?  After shanking a thousand dudes with the same old boring metal icepick and trying to follow a plot shot out of some crackpot consipracy theorist's adolescent boner I have no wish to follow the sequels of an I.P. that's been ♥♥♥♥♥ into the ground.

From now on I'm researching the ♥♥♥♥ out of all these old games Steam is rehashing to the unknowing public before buying this crap.

reviewText:
You might be thinking you loved the newest Far Cry game and wouldn't mind checking out the first Far Cry for nostalgia or video game series completionist's sake.  That playing this game would be a fun way to see how the series started and how FPS games evolved.  You might be thinking, sure, I'll grab it on the cheap and give it a quick run through.  Should be fun, right?

That's what you might be thinking as you look at this page out of curiosity or debate purchasing since there's a Steam sale and you can get this SO cheap right now.

Think again.  While it may have been great in it's prime when it first released, Far Cry is one of those games that just does NOT stand the test of time.  I lost hours of my life that I'll never get back.  Don't make the same mistake, friend.

Run while you still can.

reviewText:
Pros: graphics, binoculars, interesting ai faction battles & guns

Cons: EVERYTHING ELSE!  *DON'T BUY THIS GAME!* Horrible voice acting, dumbass story, no saves (checkpoints instead). I beat it on medium and this is the most frustrating game ever.Youll die constantly and you cant save.

Calling the AI hard is an understatement.  The AI cheats. Outright blatant cheats. A lot of the enemies later in the game are harder to kill than your own guy.  Enemies never have to reload and will constantly spam rocket or sniper rifle shots at you when you literally have to reload after every single shot.  They shoot you through walls, they shoot you through tents, they shoot you through trees.  Sometimes they shoot you from so far away your binoculars can't even see them

Seriously, don't buy this game. Metacritic is a dirty filthy liar, this game is unbelievably stupid and stops being fun after the 5th level.

reviewText:
TL;DR version: Dying everywhere in 1 hit, on easy difficulty

A decent shooter. It has good graphics for a game made in 2004, interesting combat mechanics and vehicles. It runs well on my machine too without any lag, even at 1600x900 resolution which usually lags for most games.

However, the difficulty is insanely ridiculous, even though I am playing it at Easy difficulty after reading how people say how difficult the game is, and they aren't wrong. Enemies deal a megaton of damage, and I often have to retry the same portion more than 20 times, which is absolutely frustrating. Many reasons for this is getting surrounded by far too many enemies, getting one-shotted by rockets, or getting killed almost instantly by a machine gun once I pop my head out. The shotgun is useless junk, because it is a close-range weapon which cannot 1-shot the mutants at medium range, and I can't get to close range because they deal massive damage if I do (about 50% of my HP in one hit). The person talking to the protagonist is also speaking too softly, and a lack of subtitles doesn't help. The game is also buggy. I keep getting shot through the walls, and getting hit by rockets when I see absolutely no enemies around me. The stealth" part of the game is to hide in tall grasses and bushes

reviewText:
I'm a middle-aged gamer.  Been gaming since the Commodore 64.  I just picked this up in the Far Cry pack.  Having never played these games before just now, I feel my impression of the game is not clouded by nostalgia.  I'm unimpressed.  The opening cinematic tries to be epic and action-packed but ends up making no sense at all.  I gather some chick blew up my boat, I fell into the water - into a volcano, but not...then I get to land but there are monsters?  Then there are guys shooting at me for no reason and I end up back in the water?  I'm completely confused as to what the premise of this game is.

Gameplay - Yes the graphics are a little dated but that doesn't bother me.  The problem I have is the gameplay.  The dude swims like he has a blood alcohol content of .99.  I get it, it's water.  But I shouldn't go from pointing straight ahead to looking straight down/up.  The other beef I have is with the pistol.  I get that it's supposed to be relatively innaccurate.  But if I'm 5 feet away from some guy, I point at his head, fire, see the bullet trail go towards his head, yet I completely miss, that's a problem.

Luckily I have some other games in the franchise to try out.  If I had purchased this on its own I'd be very disappointed.

reviewText:
When Far Cry asks players to duke it out with an army of gun-toting mercenaries in the middle of a jungle, it’s just about the perfect FPS.  Thinking tactically is the name of the game when sight lines, cover, and topography must be taken into account to have any chance at success.

So what’s the problem?  It’s that this is just a fraction of the experience, and the endless string of monsters in the middle of the campaign is neither challenging to fight, nor terrifying to behold.  Combine this with characters that nobody cares about, and a shallow story that had the potential to rival BioShock's if it had been done correctly, and you wind up with a product that cannot compare to more recent shooters.

For a full review, check out:
http://amanandhismouse.com/far-cry.html

reviewText:
Because I didn't play FC as a child and thus am not wearing rose-colored glasses, i can say that Far Cry has not aged well. Normally, I'd forgive an older game of a few bad bits, but this one in particular committed one of the greatest sins in the entertainmet industry: it put me off the rest of the series.

I got this game as a 2-pack with FC2, and after 2 hours, I couldn't take the poor gameplay, nonexistent story, and inconsistent AI any longer. I put it down and never looked back. Well, I did try again a year later on an easier difficulty, and with cheat codes, but Far Cry fails to entertain. It tries to pawn off some stealth mechanics, but the AI across the whole map instantly knows exactly where you are if you so much as throw a distraction rock. This forces you to engage in combat, but far cry's gunplay is terrible and unstisfying, plagued with weapons that can't be aimed (yay random chance deciding if you can hit anyone!) and fire frozen peas intead of bullets.

This left FC2 just sitting in my library, gathering dust. I wanted nothing to do with a sequel to the awful mess that is Far Cry. Eventually, I launched FC2 out of boredom, and was floored. Far Cry 2 is one of the best FPS adventures I have ever played. The fact that the same people made both games boggles my mind.

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed this game. It was not at all what I expected, but in a good way. I expected a mindless shooter with maybe a few stealth scenes, instead there is a very intruiging story here, reminded me a bit of Half-Life. The mix of action vs stealth and strategy is just right, keeps you involved and entertained all the way. I literally couldn't put it down, had to see how the story unfolds. The graphics are a bit dated, but there are some mods out there that do wonders to this game. Oh and there are no silly achievements, treasures or secrets to be sidetracked by, so you can just focus on the story and the action - exactly the way it should be. There is multiplayer and surprisingly I still found quite a number of people online, but multiplayer isn't really my thing so just fooled around a bit and then left.

reviewText: One of my personal favorites. Revolutionary for its time when it was released in 2004, it feels a little anachronistic at times with it's ex-special-forces-turned-alcoholic protagonist (complete with bad one-liners with even worse delivery), it's then-cutting-edge technology (drivable rocket-armed Humvees, and Ospreys taken straight from Half-Life 1), and characteristically mid-2000's habit of constantly trying to show off its physics engine and bump-mapped textures.\n\nIt's nothing like modern Far Cry, but it's a blast to play, especially for its price.

reviewText:
Awful cheesy writing. Good Controls...impossible scenarios. Kind of like the action movies we all loved from the 80s, in video game form. But impossibly long...everytime I thought it was going to be over or near the end it just keeps going. In some ways i'd like to consider that high value, but I guess for me I prefer my FPS games a bit shorter.

One other complaint that I am sure is included in most other reviews, is there is a terrible glitch that causes the enemy to easily target and shoot you through walls in some areas, as if the wall isn't even there. This can get very annoying at times. But thankfully it only occurs in certain places, and you can adapt your strategy to work around this problem.

I suspect when it came out this game introduced a lot of new concepts to the FPS genre, and even by todays standards it isn't a terrible game. However I don't know that playing it is really necessary unless you're hardcore and want to play every FPS or every Far Cry game in the series.

Final Verdict: Not amazing by today's standards (obviously as it has been around for at least a decade). I wouldn't recommend for the casual FPS player like myself. However for those looking for older style FPS game play with higher difficulty which requires a bit of strategy and guerrilla tactics, and a lack of gimmicks that make the game easier (like slow-mo in F.E.A.R.) this game is still pretty solid.

2004 Rating: 9/10 (1 point off for the cheesy scenes with Val)
2014 Rating: 7/10
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Far Cry (1) was my first experience with the Far Cry franchise and I'm glad I started with it instead of 2, 3, or even 4. Although the graphics are dated (it's 11 years old at this point) and other mechanics of the game were lacking or missing that can be found in modern shooters, I seriously loved this game. I have a weakness for old-school-style shooters and even though this was a 2004 title, it felt older in a way, in a good way. It's hard to explain but little things like the 90's-sounding music (I think the 90's never really went away until 2006 or so), the Duke Nukem-esque punchlines, the horrible voice acting, and the crude view models just made the game feel right. All of these things might be bad to people but I think it was a fun experience. The weapon variety was low but the enemies had a lot more variety as the game went on. I was surprised at how advanced and smooth the physics were for a game as old as this. Corpses were never stationary. You could always shoot them and see them slide, run through a banner and watch it swing realistically, and push things around at will. Very cool feature in a game that redefined the genre for it's time. The game is damn hard sometimes too. I played on the 3rd hardest difficulty and still found myself ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the game ready to quit. It's a serious challenge at times. Low on ammo, no armor left, low health, and still plenty of grenade-tossing enemies out there makes for a really interesting time. It's rewarding though to play through a checkpoint 30 times and FINALLY make it to the next one in one piece. There is no spoon-feeding on this game when it comes to difficulty. Enemy AI is relentlessly fast, attentive, and accurate. It works though because if this game had dumb or slow AI, the game would be too easy and not have that me-against-a-small-army-feel. You always feel outnumbered but not usually outgunned (Except for Krieger and Crow). You could be across the beach half a kilometer away laying down in bushes and a guy will notice you and raise the alarm. Damn. Better go back and try again from the checkpoint. Which leads me to my next point. The checkpoints on this game are HORRID. If there was one thing that made me think What in the hell were the develoeprs thinking?" it was the checkpoints. AWFUL. They were so far between that dying once could mean redoing over an hour's worth of tedious sneaking and fragging. The worst was the final boss (Krieger) in which you could kill him
date: run around to the next elevator
recommended: pause (thinking that by now the game HAS TO have saved and put you at a new checkpoint)
hoursPlayed: click back to the last checkpoint
voteText: and the game STILL didn't save your boss progress or create a new checkpoint: It would then spawn me back to the beginning of the boss fight (that I BARELY made it through on accident after 57 attempts. I guess 58 attempts never hurt?). Other than the checkpoints this game really kicked ♥♥♥. It had a good barebones feel
votesHelpful: witty cutscenes
votesTotal: no nonsense but challenging gameplay
votesFunny: a cliche storyline (that at the time I think was probably inventive or still interesting)
commentsCount: and a likeable protagonist. I really couldn't ask for much more. 9/10 for Far Cry."

reviewText:
Only recommended if you enjoy a bit of a challenge otherwise not recommended.

Definitely your grandfather's FPS.  By that I mean absolutely brutal difficulty where one guy can gun you down in under 2 seconds, health packs and armor pickups are the only way to regain health and an AI with an almost omniscient ability to spot you instantly in even the densest jungle foliage from 6 miles off or hear you crouch walking 2 rooms over.  Also, checkpoint only saving which can result in replaying certain parts over, and over, and over...

Only play if you have an indomitable spirit and a fair amount of patience.  If you are a run and gun style player, you might wanna skip the first in this series or play on one of the easy difficulties.
