reviewText: Though not the deepest of experiences, and still quite a tall order on even a modern non-gaming PC, Far Cry is still pretty fun. But be warned-- behind the reassuring veneer of campy-as-hell voice acting and action setpiece-packed first hour or so, this game is pretty hard, yo. The checkpoints are sparsely laid, and getting past every enemy camp is a twenty-minute ordeal of tagging all the enemies with the binoculars, taking out the snipers, waiting for someone to wander off alone, shooting them, moving to a new hiding spot, waiting for the heat to die down, and repeating. This is all because attempting anything other than the methodical stealthy approach will get you swiftly killed, because the player character's bullet resistance is vaguely realistic, and the enemies can see you from literally a mile away.\n\nEssentially, this is the poor man's version of Crysis, in which you have to take on a vast army in the jungle alone and without a superpowered nanosuit because you don't own a NASA supercomputer.

reviewText: Hold on, you're about tumble down into the abyss of negativity about how old this game is, just read this before you do. FarCry (the original, the classic, the brutal premier) is a somewhat dated but extremely satisfying experience. Unlike most titles, this game uses a combat engine similar to Counter Strike, in which every bullet won't be accurate if you're running or moving. In addition to ability to lean around corners, you also have a stamina bar and health doesn't regenerate. This classic example of fps  creativity was new, but is now nonexistent in MOST first-person games today. If you're looking for another positive aspect to this shooter (other than it's lush and vibrant graphics that still hold up on a polished engine) then look no further, for there is a level editor buried in the Bin folder, and it is exactly the same as the other FarCry editors. Is this game worth your time and cash? Definitely, pick it up, play it, and try to imagine this year is 2004.

reviewText: Even games with the best of intentions come and go, if they fall short in a couple key areas, to be eventually shuffled off to the graveyard of industry footnotes. A new graphical innovation here, a good sense of humor there, but something just doesn't gel. With Far Cry, however, you can see so many places where things could have gone wrong, but didn't. The AI could easily have been blindly aggressive or stone deaf. The load times could have been constant and distracting. In almost all major areas, Far Cry manages to walk the tightrope of game design over a chasm of Things Gone Wrong. I've always wondered why no one apparently tried to license the AI of the Marines in Half-Life, because after that, I was always a little bit disappointed with the FPSs that came after. And finally someone has answered the call and the creatures here are actually smart.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I only played this game out of some sort of self imposed obligation to at least see where the franchise came from. Having played instincts before this, I can say that this game is better in almost every regard, combat, stealth, pacing and otherwise, but I am still dissapointed that you never get the predator mode which instincts offered. Be that as it may it was still a competent game. But that isn't enough to get a passing grade.

This games story is dumb. I mean it is B-movie dumb and the intro you get to explain your involvment is a wordless acid trip that leaves you more confused then informed, it is literally a wordless sequence of unrelated three second clips. The voice acting and dialog of the main character is laughable and it is made more apparent by the fact that everyone else sounds and talks reasonably, it has a distinct feel of satire to it that I'm not sure is intended but is actually kind of charming and funny, but not enough to save it.

The gameplay is fairly tight, with an armor and health system, well placed checkpoints, solid stealth system for such a dated game, and a good variety of enemies and weapons.

It's not the prettiest game, but hey that won't be why you play it.

Story: 4/10
Gameplay: 7/10

reviewText:
This game is much better than Far Cry 2(do not buy), and just a little worse than Far Cry 3. It's really fun and has great graphics.

+PROS

-Great graphics for the time,
-Action Packed,
-Stealth is fun,
-Great guns,
-Big world,
-Wide, open world with lots of exploration to be done,
-[http://www.moddb.com/mods/iron-sights] An iron sights mod	 [/url] which makes it much more fun!

-Cons

-Aging graphics,
-Mods needed to add iron sights
-Some bugs, not game ruining
-Weak AI, stupid on lower difficulty,
-Some areas lack detail.

No cons ruin the game, and it is worth £6.99 (or however many dollars), and if it's on sale, I would say get it ASAP.

reviewText:
Starting with the technical, Far Cry is a first-person shooter.  It was released in early 2004, to many positive reviews gaining a meta score of 89.  It uses the CryENGINE, now known as CryENGINE1, and was the first game released by CryTek, the same company that would go on to create Crysis.  It’s their party, they’ll ‘cry’ if that want too.

At the time of writing this I haven’t completed the game, but felt as though I’d played enough to get this posted.  But believe me, that fact has nothing to do with Far Cry falling short.  With my Radeon HD 4650 and 4 GB RAM I was able to push all the graphic settings to their max, for a very beautiful game.  But lets face it, its hard to find an ugly game that came out after aught-four.

As a non-linear sandbox game you have free range over an entire island, an island over run by bizarre mutants and mercenaries that are trying to kill you, but free range none-the-less.  As the game starts you quickly learn that this is not just a good AI, but a smart one, that works together.  I’ve seen this AI do things that blew my mind, but in the good way.  I’ve been flanked on both sides at the same time, I had heavy fire from the right distract me from a Merc sneaking up on my left.  If these are just totally random moments or in the AI code I haven’t a clue, but it always kept me on my feet.

Now I can’t comment too much on the story, I know a few things, but a lot of it I’ve missed.  And that brings us to the first problem.  You see periodically you have these little chats with a fellow named Doyle, but the audio is always low, really low.  The only times I’ve heard them is A) when I got the headphones on, or B) when I know they are coming and I crank up the speakers.  If I played the game with the speakers blasting I would never miss a convo, but the volume level required is almost absurd, and if combat is going on you can’t even hear it over the gunfire and shouts.  Messing around with the audio options doesn’t solve this, at least not to any degree I’ve found. Now the really important story line stuff happens in cut scenes, so you always have the big pieces to the puzzle, plus there is a chance that this is an issue with the Steam version.  So I’m not knocking it too hard for it.

Gameplay mechanics are everything that you expect in a shooter.  Because really not a lot has changed since ’04. Some weapons have alt fire, some have different fire modes, some have scopes.  There are a good variety to choose from, but not so many that your flooded with choices.  However you can only hold four weapons at a time, so some picking and choosing is necessary. One slight annoyance I’ve found is with ladders, sometimes when you reach the top the game doesn’t want you to get off, especially if there is a lip between the ladder and the landing. Oh, and sometimes the ragdolls land wrong, but this is something I’ve seen in even the most current games.

That covers all the major stuff without taking too much away from anyone who hasn’t played Far Cry.  If you’re on the fence about, go find a copy or grab it on steam, it’s well worth the $9.99. I’ve owned the game for just over two weeks and have already logged 16 hours into it, given my schedule, that says a lot.  It’s got your vehicles to drive, helicopters to shoot down, stealthy places for stealth, and run-out-guns-blazing action.  And best of all, you get to pick how you do what, where, and when.  You make it your own game.

So a little more about the story, more so the ending.  Or the fact that you think it’s about to end, three times.  And by the time you get to the actual ending you’re somewhat surprised that it really ended. How this ranks on your personal scale will vary for everyone.  But for me this just kept the game amazing.  I think there were four times where I thought I had finished the game.

They even pull what I call the Half-Life-Moment (named after Half-Life the first game I saw do it), where you are stripped of everything and must continue on with no weapons or equipment. Always makes for a great moment and a real test of your skills.  Even if, like in this case, it’s a test of how fast can you run.

A gun with only ten bullets in it, a Trigen charging me, and me needing to get to the other side of the island.  This part was the first time that I had to resort to checking a guide on how to get past it. I’d say I spent far too much time trying to figure it, mostly due to over-thinking the problem.  Really it’s a case of the simplest answer with the most convenient definition.

And that’s another thing to really love about this, they change it up on you fairly often. The play style can switch pretty quickly, and if your not ready for it, you’ll spend hours trying to figure out how to get past a spot.  Only to eventually realize that you were going at it the wrong way. The need to stop think and assess is very common.

Stepping aside from the game for a moment, and into the compatibly realm.  Since this is a Steam game, compatibly it pretty much a guarantee, but there are a couple snags.  Other than the previously mentioned floating ragdolls, FarCry has a habit of crashing on exit.  Really it’s less of a crash and more of a freezing.  A simple Ctrl+Alt+Del and into the Task Manager to end the process will take care of the problem without any game data loss.  So a small nuisance.

Another bug is if you kill an enemy at the exact right time the audio clip of his machine gun will get stuck.  You’ll hear the gun fire, you’ll see the corpse, you can walk up and take the weapon, but the fire never stops.  You can tell the exact spot where they died, based on where the sound is the loudest, and so eventually you wont hear it any more as you leave the area.  This was never a serious issue, the sound wasn’t enough of a distraction to cause problems.  But was always pretty humorous.

Not quite a bug, but a flaw in the modeling itself was this. It just annoyed me that they thought that that looked good, and didn’t take the time to flip the model around for a better look.

I still missed most of the story early on in the game, but caught enough towards the end to get it figured out.  I did predict a classic “Hollywood Twist” and ended up being right about it. But was really disappointed with the ending, or lack there was.  Massive battle outside, having to load the save over twenty times, finally get inside the building, fire one bullet, cutscene, cutscene, end.  It really didn’t feel like an ending, and considering how many times it did feel like an ending prior to that.  I was a bit disappointed.

But now after spending 28 hours of my life inside the world of Far Cry, having beaten the game I can truly say, it’s well worth the money.  I got a hell of a bargain, but even for $9.99 it’s a steal.

reviewText:
Far Cry was a real game-changer in the FPS genre. In fact, it still holds up pretty well. The dialogue and voice acting are cartoonishly bad, but the ability to engage enemies on your own terms was and still is VERY refreshing. You can run in guns blazing, snipe targets from a distance, create distractions to draw people away, or even sneak past most places. There are a lot of guns, and the inventory restrictions ensure you don't get too complacent with any one weapon.

The visuals obviously haven't aged well, but they still have an old charm to them. Add to that a dynamic soundtrack composed by Inon Zur and some strategc level design and Far Cry is an aesthetically pleasing package. The plot kind of drags on, especially in the later chapters, but the philosophy of open combat areas and multiple ways to approach them hardly ever slows down. Not to mention, vehicles are a blast to drive.

So, who is Far Cry for? I guess in a nutshell, it's for anybody looking for a unique and still largely-untouched style of FPS and doesn't need super-clear objectives or an engrossing/serious story. It's for anybody who is seriously interested in the history of the FPS genre. I'd put it up there with the likes of DOOM, Half-Life, and BioShock. Despite being 10 years old, it's aged gracefully and it never tries to take itself too seriously. Absolutely a must-buy.

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed this game. It was not at all what I expected, but in a good way. I expected a mindless shooter with maybe a few stealth scenes, instead there is a very intruiging story here, reminded me a bit of Half-Life. The mix of action vs stealth and strategy is just right, keeps you involved and entertained all the way. I literally couldn't put it down, had to see how the story unfolds. The graphics are a bit dated, but there are some mods out there that do wonders to this game. Oh and there are no silly achievements, treasures or secrets to be sidetracked by, so you can just focus on the story and the action - exactly the way it should be. There is multiplayer and surprisingly I still found quite a number of people online, but multiplayer isn't really my thing so just fooled around a bit and then left.

reviewText: Far Cry (1) was my first experience with the Far Cry franchise and I'm glad I started with it instead of 2, 3, or even 4. Although the graphics are dated (it's 11 years old at this point) and other mechanics of the game were lacking or missing that can be found in modern shooters, I seriously loved this game. I have a weakness for old-school-style shooters and even though this was a 2004 title, it felt older in a way, in a good way. It's hard to explain but little things like the 90's-sounding music (I think the 90's never really went away until 2006 or so), the Duke Nukem-esque punchlines, the horrible voice acting, and the crude view models just made the game feel right. All of these things might be bad to people but I think it was a fun experience. The weapon variety was low but the enemies had a lot more variety as the game went on. I was surprised at how advanced and smooth the physics were for a game as old as this. Corpses were never stationary. You could always shoot them and see them slide, run through a banner and watch it swing realistically, and push things around at will. Very cool feature in a game that redefined the genre for it's time. The game is damn hard sometimes too. I played on the 3rd hardest difficulty and still found myself ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the game ready to quit. It's a serious challenge at times. Low on ammo, no armor left, low health, and still plenty of grenade-tossing enemies out there makes for a really interesting time. It's rewarding though to play through a checkpoint 30 times and FINALLY make it to the next one in one piece. There is no spoon-feeding on this game when it comes to difficulty. Enemy AI is relentlessly fast, attentive, and accurate. It works though because if this game had dumb or slow AI, the game would be too easy and not have that me-against-a-small-army-feel. You always feel outnumbered but not usually outgunned (Except for Krieger and Crow). You could be across the beach half a kilometer away laying down in bushes and a guy will notice you and raise the alarm. Damn. Better go back and try again from the checkpoint. Which leads me to my next point. The checkpoints on this game are HORRID. If there was one thing that made me think What in the hell were the develoeprs thinking?" it was the checkpoints. AWFUL. They were so far between that dying once could mean redoing over an hour's worth of tedious sneaking and fragging. The worst was the final boss (Krieger) in which you could kill him
date: run around to the next elevator
recommended: pause (thinking that by now the game HAS TO have saved and put you at a new checkpoint)
hoursPlayed: click back to the last checkpoint
voteText: and the game STILL didn't save your boss progress or create a new checkpoint: It would then spawn me back to the beginning of the boss fight (that I BARELY made it through on accident after 57 attempts. I guess 58 attempts never hurt?). Other than the checkpoints this game really kicked ♥♥♥. It had a good barebones feel
votesHelpful: witty cutscenes
votesTotal: no nonsense but challenging gameplay
votesFunny: a cliche storyline (that at the time I think was probably inventive or still interesting)
commentsCount: and a likeable protagonist. I really couldn't ask for much more. 9/10 for Far Cry."

reviewText: This game will always hold a special place in my heart as the game that introduced me to first person shooters. This and Call of Duty 1 were those games. When I was about 7-8 years old I didn't understand at first at how insanely difficult this game is and how much skill it takes to beat it at least at medium difficulty. I was just replaying random levels that my dad already completed. Then in 2015 I finally got to play it again after all these years and it felt amazing. This game will ♥♥♥♥ you up. It is extemely difficult when you get to the second half of the game and those annoying ♥♥♥♥ing mutants come out. Nevertheless , the gameplay is what makes this game great. It has great variety of guns , vehicles and it has an open way to complete your objectives. But like I said , everything gets thrown out of the window when the second half of the game comes. Think of it as the dark souls of fps games. Anyway I highly recommend you try this out as this is a must play true classic and you will notice how different this is from your typical cod and battlefield.

reviewText: Far Cry is about a man with a military background that has been hired to escort a woman by boat to a tropical island. This is not told to you from the beginning, so the intro movie can seem quite weird, as it is sort of a mixture of things happening in the present, and things to come. Your boat gets blown up, the woman takes off on a jet ski, and you swim to shore, where you meet a man over the radio that continues to give you new objectives throughout the entire game, because you're so invested in the safety of the woman.. The story evolves into being a type of umbrella corporation meets jurrasic park, where bio engineering is being done on different life forms to create a new breed of weaponry, and it's up to you to put an end to it. The graphics are sharp, a little dated, but nice. The way the character you play as speaks makes you want to punch him, but otherwise, the voices are fine. The game itself is around 12-ish hours, and is HARD. The difficulty ranges from easy to impossible. I played on medium, and there were areas that I would die within seconds of loading from the checkpoint. It's a fun game though, with varied environments, lots of story content, and game mechanics.

reviewText:
For those familiar with the FPS genre:

If you find yourself thinking that newer shooters just aren't hard enough, even on their highest difficulty, then you should definitely consider Far Cry.
I'll be the first to admit that the game is a bit dated and that I shows in nearly every aspect; from the hard edged geometries, to the dialog, to the repetitive mission goals. However, it is in these older designs that the real challenge of the game is born. Having a finite amount of health at any moment and a highly perishable flak jacket means that trying to tackle the objective by running straight at it will (7 out of 10 times conservatively) result in you having to reload a save, even on easy. Another little gem is that the AI detection is so acute that cover has little advantage other than it's ability to stop incoming bullets.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Far Cry was a real game-changer in the FPS genre. In fact, it still holds up pretty well. The dialogue and voice acting are cartoonishly bad, but the ability to engage enemies on your own terms was and still is VERY refreshing. You can run in guns blazing, snipe targets from a distance, create distractions to draw people away, or even sneak past most places. There are a lot of guns, and the inventory restrictions ensure you don't get too complacent with any one weapon.

The visuals obviously haven't aged well, but they still have an old charm to them. Add to that a dynamic soundtrack composed by Inon Zur and some strategc level design and Far Cry is an aesthetically pleasing package. The plot kind of drags on, especially in the later chapters, but the philosophy of open combat areas and multiple ways to approach them hardly ever slows down. Not to mention, vehicles are a blast to drive.

So, who is Far Cry for? I guess in a nutshell, it's for anybody looking for a unique and still largely-untouched style of FPS and doesn't need super-clear objectives or an engrossing/serious story. It's for anybody who is seriously interested in the history of the FPS genre. I'd put it up there with the likes of DOOM, Half-Life, and BioShock. Despite being 10 years old, it's aged gracefully and it never tries to take itself too seriously. Absolutely a must-buy.

Your boat gets blown up, the woman takes off on a jet ski, and you swim to shore, where you meet a man over the radio that continues to give you new objectives throughout the entire game, because you're so invested in the safety of the woman.. The story evolves into being a type of umbrella corporation meets jurrasic park, where bio engineering is being done on different life forms to create a new breed of weaponry, and it's up to you to put an end to it. The graphics are sharp, a little dated, but nice. The way the character you play as speaks makes you want to punch him, but otherwise, the voices are fine. reviewText: I never got around to playing this when it was new: so this is a review based on how I view it today.  Overall a pretty good game, you can see how this game heavily influenced games today.  This game however pulls heavily from things people liked about Battlefield 1942 and Counter Strike in terms of gameplay, reload time, and hit detection.  A very good FPS single player game with monsters and soldiers.... that being said:  I found myself getting bored due to random difficulty between levels.  FLY through 2 levels and get stuck fighting a helecopter for a 30 mins.  The highlights - Good gun play, shooting, and the vehicles are fun.  The bad is very poor/Cheating AI and appears to be sandbox gameplay but its not.  I recomend as a discount fps but there is better out now. - oh yea... Cheesy story!

reviewText:
JEEZ. This game is definately not for the faint-hearted. Generally, it's a hard ♥♥♥ game; no running and gunning here. I've spent quite a bit of my time in this game crawling along the ground at a glacial pace through tall grass and shrubbery to off one or two man-dudes to move a few more meters then off two more then sneak to the big ole' escape vehicle. But then, next thing I know, I'm behind a box fending for my life against waves of gun-toting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s praying to God that they won't flank my ♥♥♥♥ and turn me into peppered steak.
The guns in this game are some of the most satisfying I've ever used. Solid weapon models, solid gunshots, and all the enemies are good n' squishy to soak up all the lead I'm throwing at them.
This game is old enough to still have the good stuff: peekin' and leanin', prone crawling, Serious Sam-esque voice acting, and geneically mutated monkeys straight from Doom ♥♥♥♥ing three.
This game is straight-up legendary.
I'll recommend this game all day, every day.

reviewText: Far Cry (1) was my first experience with the Far Cry franchise and I'm glad I started with it instead of 2, 3, or even 4. Although the graphics are dated (it's 11 years old at this point) and other mechanics of the game were lacking or missing that can be found in modern shooters, I seriously loved this game. I have a weakness for old-school-style shooters and even though this was a 2004 title, it felt older in a way, in a good way. It's hard to explain but little things like the 90's-sounding music (I think the 90's never really went away until 2006 or so), the Duke Nukem-esque punchlines, the horrible voice acting, and the crude view models just made the game feel right. All of these things might be bad to people but I think it was a fun experience. The weapon variety was low but the enemies had a lot more variety as the game went on. I was surprised at how advanced and smooth the physics were for a game as old as this. Corpses were never stationary. You could always shoot them and see them slide, run through a banner and watch it swing realistically, and push things around at will. Very cool feature in a game that redefined the genre for it's time. The game is damn hard sometimes too. I played on the 3rd hardest difficulty and still found myself ♥♥♥♥♥♥ at the game ready to quit. It's a serious challenge at times. Low on ammo, no armor left, low health, and still plenty of grenade-tossing enemies out there makes for a really interesting time. It's rewarding though to play through a checkpoint 30 times and FINALLY make it to the next one in one piece. There is no spoon-feeding on this game when it comes to difficulty. Enemy AI is relentlessly fast, attentive, and accurate. It works though because if this game had dumb or slow AI, the game would be too easy and not have that me-against-a-small-army-feel. You always feel outnumbered but not usually outgunned (Except for Krieger and Crow). You could be across the beach half a kilometer away laying down in bushes and a guy will notice you and raise the alarm. Damn. Better go back and try again from the checkpoint. Which leads me to my next point. The checkpoints on this game are HORRID. If there was one thing that made me think What in the hell were the develoeprs thinking?" it was the checkpoints. AWFUL. They were so far between that dying once could mean redoing over an hour's worth of tedious sneaking and fragging. The worst was the final boss (Krieger) in which you could kill him
date: run around to the next elevator
recommended: pause (thinking that by now the game HAS TO have saved and put you at a new checkpoint)
hoursPlayed: click back to the last checkpoint
voteText: and the game STILL didn't save your boss progress or create a new checkpoint: It would then spawn me back to the beginning of the boss fight (that I BARELY made it through on accident after 57 attempts. I guess 58 attempts never hurt?). Other than the checkpoints this game really kicked ♥♥♥. It had a good barebones feel
votesHelpful: witty cutscenes
votesTotal: no nonsense but challenging gameplay
votesFunny: a cliche storyline (that at the time I think was probably inventive or still interesting)
commentsCount: and a likeable protagonist. I really couldn't ask for much more. 9/10 for Far Cry."

It can be pretty fun though when a miracle happens and a room fills up. If you want a challenging FPS, this is for you.

reviewText:
The main difference between this game and the newer versions is the perception of time. I have spent about 3 hours on both Far Cry and Far Cry 3. I have enoyed playing both but Far Cry has been more of a challenge all the way through. In 3 hours I feel like I have seen so much of the island and am about half-way through the game. In  3 hours on Far Cry 3 I feel like I have barely made a blip in the world. But this review is not about comparing games that were released 10 years apart!

I don't normally play shooters and this game is very much a shooter. The binocular mechanic is cool and there is enough story to pull me through. I have found many of the levels very challenging, some taking multiple attempts to clear a stage. Each attempt makes me think and plan ahead. What weapon should I use? How can I use the environment to my advantage? How can I be stealthy in a game with very poor stealth mechanics? These choices and thought processes I feel are absent from the modern shooter.

The gameplay and story is linear. It follows a protagonist who's name I can't remember but  is the overly 'manly-man' (With some classic one-liners) as his private yaught is blow up and his girlfriend is captured by pirates? You are aided by a mysterious voice from the radio as you fight your way across the island in search of your girlfriend.

You can only alter the path slightly but you will always reach the same checkpoint. There is very little else to do other than the story. No money, collectibles etc. This feels refreshing for once. Most games have hundreds of achievements and collectibles that keep you in the game long after it is fun.

The graphics are pretty decent for a 10-year old game and the environments look nice when viewed at a distance.

The AI is dumb.  The controls are okay.

For the $10 I paid for the franchise pack (1-Blood Dragon) it was a worthwhile purchase and I look forward to completing the game. You just can't go into the game expecting a modern shooter or something comparable to Far Cry 3.

On a side note:
I haven't played the multiplayer but apparently it's dead anyway. Not surprising for a 10 year old game really. Still worth the $1 or so I spent on it.

reviewText: Apparently I played this game about 124 hours to date and I think that's a wrong number. I figure I played the game 5 times that and maybe 10 times that. It's a great game. The eye candy is about as pleasant as can be for a PC that has limits on graphics power. It's a great game for single player action with the headphones on, on a rainy day outside and you're in the tropics, everything blue and sunny and your listening to jungle birds making nice sounds, waves lapping the beach and your looking for baddies. It's a classic. The enemy are not the smartest but they where never intended to be the smartest. This is a practice game, a learner, a reliable experience from beginning to end and you're going to love the scenery because it's nice to look at. The monsters are horrible and deserve no mercy and so it's easy fraging them and the enemy is a mix of fools, idiots and really bad nasty people. The vehicles are very good and the sound is very good. Make sure you can play it on the highest settings because this game looks very nice at the highest settings and that's when all the birds, little fish and insects com out. It's a classic and in the best of the best first person shooters of all time. There so many maps available for the game and there are map packs that are better than the game's original maps that are already excellent. You could buy this game, play out it's maps, install map packs and play it for years and never see the same map twice. A very good game with very good community support and it's very very stable with a PC built about 3-4 years after the game's release date. Around the game's release date the PCs had some issues with the game but that all changed when the PCs improved and software updates where released. The game is now solid. Buy it. You'll love it.

reviewText:
Starting with the technical, Far Cry is a first-person shooter.  It was released in early 2004, to many positive reviews gaining a meta score of 89.  It uses the CryENGINE, now known as CryENGINE1, and was the first game released by CryTek, the same company that would go on to create Crysis.  It’s their party, they’ll ‘cry’ if that want too.

At the time of writing this I haven’t completed the game, but felt as though I’d played enough to get this posted.  But believe me, that fact has nothing to do with Far Cry falling short.  With my Radeon HD 4650 and 4 GB RAM I was able to push all the graphic settings to their max, for a very beautiful game.  But lets face it, its hard to find an ugly game that came out after aught-four.

As a non-linear sandbox game you have free range over an entire island, an island over run by bizarre mutants and mercenaries that are trying to kill you, but free range none-the-less.  As the game starts you quickly learn that this is not just a good AI, but a smart one, that works together.  I’ve seen this AI do things that blew my mind, but in the good way.  I’ve been flanked on both sides at the same time, I had heavy fire from the right distract me from a Merc sneaking up on my left.  If these are just totally random moments or in the AI code I haven’t a clue, but it always kept me on my feet.

Now I can’t comment too much on the story, I know a few things, but a lot of it I’ve missed.  And that brings us to the first problem.  You see periodically you have these little chats with a fellow named Doyle, but the audio is always low, really low.  The only times I’ve heard them is A) when I got the headphones on, or B) when I know they are coming and I crank up the speakers.  If I played the game with the speakers blasting I would never miss a convo, but the volume level required is almost absurd, and if combat is going on you can’t even hear it over the gunfire and shouts.  Messing around with the audio options doesn’t solve this, at least not to any degree I’ve found. Now the really important story line stuff happens in cut scenes, so you always have the big pieces to the puzzle, plus there is a chance that this is an issue with the Steam version.  So I’m not knocking it too hard for it.

Gameplay mechanics are everything that you expect in a shooter.  Because really not a lot has changed since ’04. Some weapons have alt fire, some have different fire modes, some have scopes.  There are a good variety to choose from, but not so many that your flooded with choices.  However you can only hold four weapons at a time, so some picking and choosing is necessary. One slight annoyance I’ve found is with ladders, sometimes when you reach the top the game doesn’t want you to get off, especially if there is a lip between the ladder and the landing. Oh, and sometimes the ragdolls land wrong, but this is something I’ve seen in even the most current games.

That covers all the major stuff without taking too much away from anyone who hasn’t played Far Cry.  If you’re on the fence about, go find a copy or grab it on steam, it’s well worth the $9.99. I’ve owned the game for just over two weeks and have already logged 16 hours into it, given my schedule, that says a lot.  It’s got your vehicles to drive, helicopters to shoot down, stealthy places for stealth, and run-out-guns-blazing action.  And best of all, you get to pick how you do what, where, and when.  You make it your own game.

So a little more about the story, more so the ending.  Or the fact that you think it’s about to end, three times.  And by the time you get to the actual ending you’re somewhat surprised that it really ended. How this ranks on your personal scale will vary for everyone.  But for me this just kept the game amazing.  I think there were four times where I thought I had finished the game.

They even pull what I call the Half-Life-Moment (named after Half-Life the first game I saw do it), where you are stripped of everything and must continue on with no weapons or equipment. Always makes for a great moment and a real test of your skills.  Even if, like in this case, it’s a test of how fast can you run.

A gun with only ten bullets in it, a Trigen charging me, and me needing to get to the other side of the island.  This part was the first time that I had to resort to checking a guide on how to get past it. I’d say I spent far too much time trying to figure it, mostly due to over-thinking the problem.  Really it’s a case of the simplest answer with the most convenient definition.

And that’s another thing to really love about this, they change it up on you fairly often. The play style can switch pretty quickly, and if your not ready for it, you’ll spend hours trying to figure out how to get past a spot.  Only to eventually realize that you were going at it the wrong way. The need to stop think and assess is very common.

Stepping aside from the game for a moment, and into the compatibly realm.  Since this is a Steam game, compatibly it pretty much a guarantee, but there are a couple snags.  Other than the previously mentioned floating ragdolls, FarCry has a habit of crashing on exit.  Really it’s less of a crash and more of a freezing.  A simple Ctrl+Alt+Del and into the Task Manager to end the process will take care of the problem without any game data loss.  So a small nuisance.

Another bug is if you kill an enemy at the exact right time the audio clip of his machine gun will get stuck.  You’ll hear the gun fire, you’ll see the corpse, you can walk up and take the weapon, but the fire never stops.  You can tell the exact spot where they died, based on where the sound is the loudest, and so eventually you wont hear it any more as you leave the area.  This was never a serious issue, the sound wasn’t enough of a distraction to cause problems.  But was always pretty humorous.

Not quite a bug, but a flaw in the modeling itself was this. It just annoyed me that they thought that that looked good, and didn’t take the time to flip the model around for a better look.

I still missed most of the story early on in the game, but caught enough towards the end to get it figured out.  I did predict a classic “Hollywood Twist” and ended up being right about it. But was really disappointed with the ending, or lack there was.  Massive battle outside, having to load the save over twenty times, finally get inside the building, fire one bullet, cutscene, cutscene, end.  It really didn’t feel like an ending, and considering how many times it did feel like an ending prior to that.  I was a bit disappointed.

But now after spending 28 hours of my life inside the world of Far Cry, having beaten the game I can truly say, it’s well worth the money.  I got a hell of a bargain, but even for $9.99 it’s a steal.

reviewText: I played this game when it first came out and I remember loving it, so I was excited to see it on Steam and find out how it's held up all these years later.  What a wonderful suprise that this game is even better than I remember it!  The graphics may be a little dated compared to what's out right now, but they still hold up pretty good, especially the atmosphiric effects in some of the indoor maps, with distortion from steam coming out of vents and shifting shadows from swinging light fixtures.  The engine is fantastic, with great hit detection and a smooth solid shooting feel, although I did have some problems getting stuck in doorways or on ramps.  The AI is also not the brightest, but sometimes the mercenaries on the island did a pretty good job flanking me and popping out of the jungle where I wasn't expecting them.\n\nMy favorite thing about this game is the amazing setting; a lush tropical island for the player to explore.  It seems that every new map has something cool to check out, from Japanese WWII relics to sandy atol outpost to misty mountaintop research stations.  The story is pretty generic, but it does a good job at propelling you from one interesting predicament to the next.  If you have never played this game, give it a shot.  I honestly think it's superior to all of the Farcry sequels, and also a lot of other FPS games I've played in recent years.

reviewText: I thought Far Cry 2 was the hardest in the series HA HA I was so wrong. AI is very smart here and the fact that you can't save whenever you want makes it even more difficult. This game's hardest setting have some hilariously hard parts where you'll  want to punch your screen after the 40th try (the part when the girl drives and you shoot, GOD DAMN THAT PART). Although the voice acting, the cutscenes and the story are terrible, the gameplay and graphics (for its time) are superb.\n\nIt is very satisfactory when you make a headshot with your good old M4 from a long distance. A good variety of weapons. The multiplayer is still there, but you have to be lucky to find someone playing. The rooms are usually filled up with BOTS. It can be pretty fun though when a miracle happens and a room fills up. If you want a challenging FPS, this is for you.

reviewText: Perfect game in all senses. A must own!!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Overall

The tropical environments are beauitful and varied. Each section has different flora and flauna and soil and lighting (due to the different time of day). The maps are open and leave you free to use the various means at your disposal to get to your goal. The plot is amusingly B-grade Hollywood without the slightest hint of pretentiousness but still manages to surprise. The maps alternate between corridor and jungle levels and there is plenty of variety within that structure. Vehicle missions, hang-gliding, guarding a VIP, et al. The main voice actor does a funny and sometimes hilariously implausible cross between Napoleon Dynamite and Bruce Willias in Die Hard.

Also the music in some of the jungle stages is outstanding. Borrowed from Hollywood with eerie Japanese-sounding woodwinds and gongs.

I think it's an excellent shooter all around, but I especially admired it for the tense and scenic jungle stages. It's also famously difficult, about which I have some comments.

Gameplay

The first review I saw when I scanned the reviews a moment ago said this was the Dark Souls of FPSs, and I think that is a good way of putting it. It seems extremely difficult at first, but unless you have the see-through textures bug it's not cheap (although you can be the recipient of flukishly lucky headshots, just as you can be the giver). You have to play very slowly and deliberately, especially in the jungle levels, and you have to use all of the items in your arsenal, particularly the binoculars and the nightvision. Above all you have to learn to keep one eye glued to the detection meter. Not only does it tell you when you need to back off and dive into the bush, it also lets you know that there's someone out there in your field of vision if you look carefully for them.

You also have to understand that the enemies have vision approximately as good as yours (that is, if you can see them they can see you). Sometimes they can see you when it's impossible to see them because of the draw distance, but that is more than offset by the fact that even when you're in their field of vision you get a grace period while the detection meter builds up. Also when you are in cover you can see them without them seeing you.

Another point is this game has an usually high bonus for headshots versus bodyshots. It feels like about 5:1 to me. Especially against humans you should always be going for headshots, except when you're in a really bad spot where you don't have time to aim (bodyshots have a slight stunning effect against humans and armshots cause them to drop their weapons).

The one matter related to difficulty that I think should have been fixed is it should be easier to track the source of gunfire on your HUD or in the world. The reason is occasionally there is an enemy, usually situated on higher ground, who can rapidly spot you when you come out of cover. If you're not playing with quicksaves you will often find yourself with low enough health that you will be killed in one shot, and sometimes you just can't find the guy with your binoculars while in the cover of foliage. So your only hope in those situations is to sprint for new cover and hope you can find the shooter from there.

Difficulty

Without quick saves as originally designed the game's medium difficulty should have been its hardest difficulty, and the harder difficulties should have been for NG+. Personally I did the first half without quicksaves but then applied the FCAM patch for the sake of graphics and used the quicksave option that goes with it. It takes all the frustration out of the game but also most of the suspense. Without your progress being at stake it doesn't really matter if you fail. And certain very busy stages of the game become outright easy when you can save incrementally every time you manage to take out a few guys without getting hit. I would recommend playing without quicksaves for as long as you can stand it. Maybe consult a FAQ as a palliative.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Only recommended if you enjoy a bit of a challenge otherwise not recommended.

Definitely your grandfather's FPS.  By that I mean absolutely brutal difficulty where one guy can gun you down in under 2 seconds, health packs and armor pickups are the only way to regain health and an AI with an almost omniscient ability to spot you instantly in even the densest jungle foliage from 6 miles off or hear you crouch walking 2 rooms over.  Also, checkpoint only saving which can result in replaying certain parts over, and over, and over...

Only play if you have an indomitable spirit and a fair amount of patience.  If you are a run and gun style player, you might wanna skip the first in this series or play on one of the easy difficulties.

reviewText:
Well. Far Cry is a cheater, however, a cheater can only be beaten by another cheater, thats is the mentality of this Games, you have to lure your enemies one by one and one by one you kill them, the AI is paranoic, thats mean that siglest movement can alert you enemies, your life bar is weak as you can be killed with only 3 to 5 hits making this a game where you dont have get hurt at any cost, thats is for players to avoid frontal assaults on enemy camps/outpost.
The story is a little basic, you are an Ex-Seal trapped in island full of mercenaries and monsters where you have to rescue a American Girl captured inside.

Pros
>Excellent Gameplay
>Decent Stealth Mechanics

Cons

The story is pretty cheesy in my opinion, and the game is really just about killing every enemy in your path on your way to your objective, then getting a new one and repeating.

But overall the combat and weapons are fun and it's not a bad game especially for it's time.

reviewText: I played this game when it first came out and I remember loving it, so I was excited to see it on Steam and find out how it's held up all these years later.  What a wonderful suprise that this game is even better than I remember it!  The graphics may be a little dated compared to what's out right now, but they still hold up pretty good, especially the atmosphiric effects in some of the indoor maps, with distortion from steam coming out of vents and shifting shadows from swinging light fixtures.  The engine is fantastic, with great hit detection and a smooth solid shooting feel, although I did have some problems getting stuck in doorways or on ramps.  The AI is also not the brightest, but sometimes the mercenaries on the island did a pretty good job flanking me and popping out of the jungle where I wasn't expecting them.\n\nMy favorite thing about this game is the amazing setting; a lush tropical island for the player to explore.  It seems that every new map has something cool to check out, from Japanese WWII relics to sandy atol outpost to misty mountaintop research stations.  The story is pretty generic, but it does a good job at propelling you from one interesting predicament to the next.  If you have never played this game, give it a shot.  I honestly think it's superior to all of the Farcry sequels, and also a lot of other FPS games I've played in recent years.

reviewText:
JEEZ. This game is definately not for the faint-hearted. Generally, it's a hard ♥♥♥ game; no running and gunning here. I've spent quite a bit of my time in this game crawling along the ground at a glacial pace through tall grass and shrubbery to off one or two man-dudes to move a few more meters then off two more then sneak to the big ole' escape vehicle. But then, next thing I know, I'm behind a box fending for my life against waves of gun-toting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s praying to God that they won't flank my ♥♥♥♥ and turn me into peppered steak.
The guns in this game are some of the most satisfying I've ever used. Solid weapon models, solid gunshots, and all the enemies are good n' squishy to soak up all the lead I'm throwing at them.
This game is old enough to still have the good stuff: peekin' and leanin', prone crawling, Serious Sam-esque voice acting, and geneically mutated monkeys straight from Doom ♥♥♥♥ing three.
This game is straight-up legendary.
I'll recommend this game all day, every day.

reviewText:
Starting with the technical, Far Cry is a first-person shooter.  It was released in early 2004, to many positive reviews gaining a meta score of 89.  It uses the CryENGINE, now known as CryENGINE1, and was the first game released by CryTek, the same company that would go on to create Crysis.  It’s their party, they’ll ‘cry’ if that want too.

At the time of writing this I haven’t completed the game, but felt as though I’d played enough to get this posted.  But believe me, that fact has nothing to do with Far Cry falling short.  With my Radeon HD 4650 and 4 GB RAM I was able to push all the graphic settings to their max, for a very beautiful game.  But lets face it, its hard to find an ugly game that came out after aught-four.

As a non-linear sandbox game you have free range over an entire island, an island over run by bizarre mutants and mercenaries that are trying to kill you, but free range none-the-less.  As the game starts you quickly learn that this is not just a good AI, but a smart one, that works together.  I’ve seen this AI do things that blew my mind, but in the good way.  I’ve been flanked on both sides at the same time, I had heavy fire from the right distract me from a Merc sneaking up on my left.  If these are just totally random moments or in the AI code I haven’t a clue, but it always kept me on my feet.

Now I can’t comment too much on the story, I know a few things, but a lot of it I’ve missed.  And that brings us to the first problem.  You see periodically you have these little chats with a fellow named Doyle, but the audio is always low, really low.  The only times I’ve heard them is A) when I got the headphones on, or B) when I know they are coming and I crank up the speakers.  If I played the game with the speakers blasting I would never miss a convo, but the volume level required is almost absurd, and if combat is going on you can’t even hear it over the gunfire and shouts.  Messing around with the audio options doesn’t solve this, at least not to any degree I’ve found. Now the really important story line stuff happens in cut scenes, so you always have the big pieces to the puzzle, plus there is a chance that this is an issue with the Steam version.  So I’m not knocking it too hard for it.

Gameplay mechanics are everything that you expect in a shooter.  Because really not a lot has changed since ’04. Some weapons have alt fire, some have different fire modes, some have scopes.  There are a good variety to choose from, but not so many that your flooded with choices.  However you can only hold four weapons at a time, so some picking and choosing is necessary. One slight annoyance I’ve found is with ladders, sometimes when you reach the top the game doesn’t want you to get off, especially if there is a lip between the ladder and the landing. Oh, and sometimes the ragdolls land wrong, but this is something I’ve seen in even the most current games.

That covers all the major stuff without taking too much away from anyone who hasn’t played Far Cry.  If you’re on the fence about, go find a copy or grab it on steam, it’s well worth the $9.99. I’ve owned the game for just over two weeks and have already logged 16 hours into it, given my schedule, that says a lot.  It’s got your vehicles to drive, helicopters to shoot down, stealthy places for stealth, and run-out-guns-blazing action.  And best of all, you get to pick how you do what, where, and when.  You make it your own game.

So a little more about the story, more so the ending.  Or the fact that you think it’s about to end, three times.  And by the time you get to the actual ending you’re somewhat surprised that it really ended. How this ranks on your personal scale will vary for everyone.  But for me this just kept the game amazing.  I think there were four times where I thought I had finished the game.

They even pull what I call the Half-Life-Moment (named after Half-Life the first game I saw do it), where you are stripped of everything and must continue on with no weapons or equipment. Always makes for a great moment and a real test of your skills.  Even if, like in this case, it’s a test of how fast can you run.

A gun with only ten bullets in it, a Trigen charging me, and me needing to get to the other side of the island.  This part was the first time that I had to resort to checking a guide on how to get past it. I’d say I spent far too much time trying to figure it, mostly due to over-thinking the problem.  Really it’s a case of the simplest answer with the most convenient definition.

And that’s another thing to really love about this, they change it up on you fairly often. The play style can switch pretty quickly, and if your not ready for it, you’ll spend hours trying to figure out how to get past a spot.  Only to eventually realize that you were going at it the wrong way. The need to stop think and assess is very common.

Stepping aside from the game for a moment, and into the compatibly realm.  Since this is a Steam game, compatibly it pretty much a guarantee, but there are a couple snags.  Other than the previously mentioned floating ragdolls, FarCry has a habit of crashing on exit.  Really it’s less of a crash and more of a freezing.  A simple Ctrl+Alt+Del and into the Task Manager to end the process will take care of the problem without any game data loss.  So a small nuisance.

Another bug is if you kill an enemy at the exact right time the audio clip of his machine gun will get stuck.  You’ll hear the gun fire, you’ll see the corpse, you can walk up and take the weapon, but the fire never stops.  You can tell the exact spot where they died, based on where the sound is the loudest, and so eventually you wont hear it any more as you leave the area.  This was never a serious issue, the sound wasn’t enough of a distraction to cause problems.  But was always pretty humorous.

Not quite a bug, but a flaw in the modeling itself was this. It just annoyed me that they thought that that looked good, and didn’t take the time to flip the model around for a better look.

I still missed most of the story early on in the game, but caught enough towards the end to get it figured out.  I did predict a classic “Hollywood Twist” and ended up being right about it. But was really disappointed with the ending, or lack there was.  Massive battle outside, having to load the save over twenty times, finally get inside the building, fire one bullet, cutscene, cutscene, end.  It really didn’t feel like an ending, and considering how many times it did feel like an ending prior to that.  I was a bit disappointed.

But now after spending 28 hours of my life inside the world of Far Cry, having beaten the game I can truly say, it’s well worth the money.  I got a hell of a bargain, but even for $9.99 it’s a steal.

reviewText:
This is an old game.  It's one of those games that pioneered what we take for granted in a modern shooter.  Like those pioneers, it shares a similar plot; guy with military background gets sent to a secret facility to beat up grunts and fight a bad guy, who is going to release an evil plot device that will ultimately destroy the world if not stopped.

Those kinds of stories were the heyday back in the days, and Far Cry is no exception.  It's sad that what modern shooters have chosen to take from their roots to apply to their current games is just the cut-and-paste plot and the state-of-the-art graphics.  I had to stop playing this game and give it a break multiple times throughout the playthrough because I kept running into parts where the game was incredibly difficult.  This ranged from a lack of waypoints (which you find in almost every shooter game) which meant that it was nigh close to impossible to figure out where to go, to a lack of the right weapons (you'd think that having a pistol might actually be helpful in one of the early games where the great focus was the hitbox health system where headshots could one-hit-KO something), to having to deal with a horde of enemies all at once with almost no health and an escort mission to boot.  It's a game that makes you have to stop what you are doing and leave the computer for a while to think and recharge your brain cells before going back in again.

I miss that in a lot of today's games.  Shooters could do with the increased difficulty that doesn't require cheat codes or a paywall to bypass.  It's nice to take a step back from the LCD induced graphics and hardware and just play an old game in order to appreciate how far we've come.
